As an active member of the PDP-LP Program of PAGLAUM MPC, a microfinance program that reaches out to the rural poor, she has successfully repaid a loan of PHP 7,500. She is now requesting an amount of PHP 10,000 as her 3rd cycle loan to be used for additional capital for her existing businesses. The future income from this loan will be used to improve her family's living conditions, to meet their basic needs, to repay loans to PMPC and for savings, the children’s education and possible business expansions. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. </p> <br clear="all">

properties.title: Sum Phâlla : Cambodia
properties.description: <p><a rel="nofollow"><img src="http://www.kiva.org/image.php?type=thumbnail&id=590622" align="left" alt="photo" title="Sum Ph&#xe2;lla" border="1"/>   </a><b>$1,050 of $1,100 raised.<br/><br/></b> Started raising funds on Sep 1, 2010 <br/> <br/> Mrs. Sum Phâlla is a 41-year-old married woman and a local villager living in a medium-sized home with family members in Phnom Penh City. She owns a piece of farmland on which she and her husband always cultivate crops to earn a living. Besides this, she sells a few grocery ingredients out of her home and her husband provides a motor-taxi service for additional revenue. This couple are good parents of four children, one of whom is employed as an English teacher. In order to generate extra profits, Sum Phâlla needs a loan to pay for hiring a parking lot in the school which she will use to look after a student’s vehicle for a fee. (Mrs. Sum Phâlla's husband is pictured.) </p> <br clear="all">

properties.title: Mujeres Exitosas 1 & 2 Group : Dominican Republic
properties.description: <p><a rel="nofollow"><img src="http://www.kiva.org/image.php?type=thumbnail&id=588735" align="left" alt="photo" title="Mujeres Exitosas 1 & 2 Group" border="1"/>   </a><b>$2,450 of $2,575 raised.<br/><br/></b> Started raising funds on Sep 3, 2010 <br/> <br/> Susana is the coordinator of her group, Mujeres exitosas 1 & 2 (Successful women). She makes her home here in a simple structure with some of her family. She has two sons. She says that her most difficult challenges are to have charisma and patience working with people. In the meantime she plans to continue enjoying singing as a hobby every moment she can. Susana is excited to be taking her second loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She has had her business for two years, starting with a loan she had of $200 US to buy some clothes. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business by buying pants, skirts, underwear, shirts, etc. She will use the profits to improve her business and make it a successful one, with a better structure and bigger store. This Esperanza associate began with us because she wants to invest in her business and likes the facilities Esperanza offers. Her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) generally. Her group is located in Puerto Plata, a port town on the north coast where the economy is based on tourism. This area, like nearly all impoverished areas of the Dominican Republic, suffers from unreliable running water (none of which is potable) and electricity. </p> <br clear="all">

properties.title: Jose Antonio : El Salvador
properties.description: <p><a rel="nofollow"><img src="http://www.kiva.org/image.php?type=thumbnail&id=592808" align="left" alt="photo" title="Jose Antonio" border="1"/>   </a><b>$400 of $1,200 raised.<br/><br/></b> Started raising funds on Sep 2, 2010 <br/> <br/> Jose is 46 years old and he lives in the El Transito municipality in the region of Usulután. He is married and he lives with his wife and their two children, aged 4 and 13 years of age. His wife makes tortillas and he has a car that he uses as a taxi. He started out his business with the help of a friend who taught him the line of work. He works from 6am to 6pm. The challenge he faces is not having enough funds to maintain his car in good condition, neither to repair the body nor to purchase spare parts, for which reason he requests a loan. This will permit him to have his vehicle in good condition and be able to meet his clients' demands and provide them with good service. His aspirations are to have a larger business and improve his way of life. <br /><p><strong>Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer</strong></p>  <br clear="all">

properties.title: Haldi Foty Group : Senegal
properties.description: $2,175 of $3,300 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 1, 2011 The Haldi Foty group was created in May 2010 when their "village bank" was inaugurated. It is made up of 25 women, all from the same neighborhood and animated with good understanding. They are all small-scale retailers. Madame Néné (seated, third person going from left to right) is the leader of the group. She is 46, a widow, and is raising 10 children, four children of her co-spouse and one grandson. She sells fruit and vegetables, a business she has been in for three years. Her new loan will allow her to buy fruit and vegetables for resale. The profit from this business will allow her to help her children pay school fees and to feed them.

properties.title: Dalia Ortegon-Stokes : United States
properties.description: $8,400 of $9,250 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 29, 2011 Dalia’s motivation for starting her business, Stokes and Company, was born of a passion for used and re-purposed items. She developed this passion from garage sale “treasure hunting” excursions taken with her mother as a child. As she got older, Dalia realized that she also had a natural talent for decorating and design. With this combination of talent and passion as her guide, she started her own antique, clothing and women’s services store in Abilene, Texas. Dalia attributes the quick rise and success of her business to her relentless hard work along with the efforts of her husband and two children. When she first started Stokes and Company 5 years ago, it was a small booth inside of an antiques mall. “My husband persuaded me to follow my dreams, so I opened the booth. Within 6 months, it tripled in size; 6 months after that, we expanded to our own location. After 5 years, we moved from a 1200-square-foot store to our current location, nearly three times that size,” she says. Without the persistent dedication of her family, who have done everything from manage the business to repairing its buildings, Dalia believes this success would never have been possible. Stokes and Company offers its customers used and reupholstered furniture, antiques, home décor items, and clothing for women. She says that her business takes old furniture and, using her natural eye for design, repairs it to give it a “new life.” In her own words, “I feel like my business is like a jewelry box: you’ll never know what you can find when you go in there. That’s what sets me apart from others.” She believes that the unique service she provides and her store’s constantly changing inventory compel her clients to return to Stokes and Company. In the future, Dalia hopes to continue offering her customers one-of-a-kind service while expanding her business to cater to the everyday needs of women. In its new location, Dalia has split the store into two parts: one for the antiques and furniture shop and the other to serve as a studio to create custom pieces for customers. She also added a waxing salon to bring her business closer to the goal of catering to the diverse needs of her women customers. With this loan, Dalia will expand her inventory to fit the needs of her business’ new space. While the move to a 3500-square-foot location is necessary, this means that her current inventory covers only about 1/3rd of that space. After realizing that a commercial bank would not fit her business needs, Dalia reached out to Kiva's partner ACCION Texas-Louisiana. With this loan, Dalia will not only continue to serve her loyal clients, but she will expand her services to meet the needs of an even more diverse part of her community.

properties.title: Pedro Rafael : Nicaragua
properties.description: $950 of $1,200 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 3, 2011 Pedro, 43, is from the city of León. He’s married and the father of three children. He’s an Accountant by profession and also owns a bakery. He started this business at the age of 23. He used to work as an accountant for a state institution. Back then he was 18 years old. He was also taking Agricultural Engineering courses while working but it became difficult to pay for the schooling because his family was going through a difficult economic situation. He had to stop studying and had lost his job. An uncle encouraged him to set up his own business so that he could get ahead. He did so and gradually attained the bakery he has today. He asked for the loan to buy an industrial oven to increase bread production and meet customer demand increasing income through his sales. He wants to open new markets in the rural parts of León because he feels they are good sales points for his products and to buy a motorcycle to distribute his products and save on fuel. His next steps include doing some improvements to the business and modernizing some of his work tools like buying an industrial mixer.

properties.title: Haysam : Lebanon
properties.description: $650 of $2,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 22, 2011 Haysam is a 31-year-old married man and the father of one child. He has owned an electronics shop since 2005. He worked hard to open his business and improve it over this period. Haysam's shop is unique in his region. High tech is important these days and requested a lot. He works hard to add new improved technologies, and he works on marketing them as quickly as possible. He also provides Internet services and cable television networks to homes. Haysam, is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua, a Kiva partner, in order to enlarge and improve his laptop and television sales department. Haysam hopes to buy a big Internet network station, in addition to having a special accounting program in his shop.

properties.title: Yeuk : Cambodia
properties.description: $375 of $800 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 1, 2011 Mrs. Yeuk, who lives in the Prey Chor district of Kompong Tom Province, has been a farmer for a long time. She can make a profit of approximately $2.50 a day. Her husband works in the construction field and is earning around $5 a day to help with the family's daily needs. They blessed with five children; three are married and two are single. Mrs. Yeuk is concerned that one of her children is unemployed. She wants to assist her child to go to work abroad, in Korea, but her current savings are not adequate to pay for the documentation costs. So Mrs. Yeuk would like to apply for a loan which will be used to pay those document fees.

properties.title: Esperance : Rwanda
properties.description: $575 of $850 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 2, 2011 Esperance is 27 years old and married with two children between the ages of 4 and 6 years old. She sells items like rice, soap, body lotion, etc. from her boutique. Esperance has three year's experience and she works from 7 am until 11 pm every day. Esperance has requested a loan from Kiva lenders in order to expand her business to buy more rice, sugar, water, soap, body lotion and so on. With this profit, Esperance will save for her family and reinvest in her business.

properties.title: Kotognogontala 3 Group : Mali
properties.description: $250 of $1,750 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 1, 2011 The 10 members of the Kotognogontala 3 group are married women averaging 38 years of age with four children and living mainly in polygamous families in Fachoribougou, a village in the commune of Kaboila in the prefecture of Sikasso, the third administrative region of Mali. They collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to ensure the success of their agricultural activities during the winter season. They are on their eighth loan with the institution. The previous loans have been duly repaid. They cultivate tomatoes and jakatou [a vegetable from the eggplant family]--as for example, Abi (second from right standing) does. With her loan, she plans to pay the costs of labor, buy agricultural inputs and seeds to work 2 hectares [ 5 acres[ of land. After harvesting, the produce is sold at their village and at the Sikasso market, to a customer base composed of both women and men. She plans to earn an average monthly income of 65,500 West African franks per agricultural cycle. This income will allow her to pay off her loan and also help her husband with everyday expenses.

properties.title: Mercy Wairimu Mbochi : Kenya
properties.description: $100 of $250 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Mercy, a 29-year-old married mother of two children, has been operating a green grocery for three years. She works hard in her business so as to help her husband with household expenses, and through Faulu Kenya has learned how to save her money and to manage her business. Mercy is now requesting a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy vegetables and fruits. She hopes to open other business outlets in the future.

properties.title: Manal Nadia : Palestine
properties.description: $2,700 of $3,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 17, 2011 Manal is a mother of one daughter and two sons. Her young children do not have bedroom furniture yet as the parents are employees with very decent salaries but couldn't afford bedroom furniture. The couple could save a small amount of money to purchase the bedroom furniture but they needed more to be able to buy good furniture that would last for a long time, as they won't be able to replace it any time soon. Manal took out a loan from FATEN to purchase the furniture. Manal's husband appears in the picture here instead, as she is a conservative woman from GAZA.

properties.title: Embajadores 1 & 2 Group : Dominican Republic
properties.description: $2,625 of $3,125 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 28, 2011 Odania lives in a simple structure with her long-term partner and three children. She is the coordinator of her group, Embajadores 1 & 2 ("Ambassadors 1 & 2"). The group is made up of Haitian members, all of them who emigrated from Haiti during different periods. Odania's story is representative of both her group and Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients in general. Her group is located in the rural areas surrounding La Romana, where sugarcane and the tourist industry dominate the economy. Odania sells clothes such as jeans, shirts, skirts, underwear and other things for kids, women and men. She is excited to be seeking her eighth loan with Esperanza; notably, she has successfully repaid her previous loan, which enabled her to grow her business. With each of these loans she has been able to expand her business by introducing new products. Odania plans to use this loan to invest in her business and invest the profits in more merchandise. She will save some money to achieve her future plans for her business. She thanks all of you for your support.

properties.title: Bichiko Tetradze : Georgia
properties.description: $1,750 of $1,825 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 5, 2011 Bichiko comes from the village of Ganakhleba in the Dmanisi district. He is 40 years old, unmarried and lives with his father, 90-year-old Guram, who is retired. Agricultural activities, led by Bichiko, are the only source of income for the family. He works on the family-owned dairy farm with 5 milk cows and sells approximately 140 kg of cheese per month to local dairy product retailers. He also has a bee keeping farm with 30 hives and colonies. He sells the harvested honey in the village during the entire year. The family's average monthly income from farming activities is 500 GEL. Bichiko plans to use the requested loan to purchase 10 more beehives with bee colonies. The expansion of the bee keeping farm will allow Bichiko to sell more honey and get more income, thereby improving living conditions for his father and himself.

properties.title: Jose Emilio Pablo Gonzalez : Guatemala
properties.description: $850 of $1,150 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 2, 2011 Emilio has a tailor shop, called Nuevo Peren, in the village where he lives. He rents a locale to be able to work making pants, shirts, coats, ties, etc. He is very well known in town as a good tailor. He is asking for the loan to buy Sincatex (brand of polyester) fabric and, because his house is located in the Santa Anita Patzaj village, he raises pigs so is also asking for the loan to buy pig feed. His dream is to own a locale so as not to rent anymore but he needs quite a large investment because he has three school aged children.

properties.title: Weltare Group : Senegal
properties.description: $3,425 of $3,875 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 1, 2011 The Weltaré group was created in May 2010 upon the inauguration of the local Banc Villageois. It consists of 25 women who all live in the same area. Their main activity is small trade. Mrs. Fatou (sitting, third from the left) is the group leader. She is 56 years old, married, and the mother of three children. She also looks after her four nephews. She has been selling porridge in her neighborhood for over 10 years. With this new loan, she plans to purchase three sacks of millet and one bag of sugar. Part of the profits will go towards her savings, and the remainder will be used to provide for her children at home and at school.

properties.title: Las Perlas 1 Group : Mexico
properties.description: $1,375 of $1,800 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 6, 2011 This photo was taken at Elvira’s house, one of the members of the “Las Perlas 1” group which is located in the Mexican state of Veracruz. She sells bread, a business she started four years ago. She is asking for the loan to buy more supplies like flour, yeast, water and milk. Her fellow group members and neighbors know her for being a responsible, hard working person. Besides, her bread is quite delicious and she always has variety available. At the moment of requesting the loan she feels satisfied because she will be able to increase sales which will allow for higher profits and thus to help her family. Elvira is 38 years old, never went to school, is married and has a total of three children, one boy and two girls. She also hopes later on to be able to do some home improvements and to continue supporting her children’s schooling so that they will have a better future.

properties.title: Oscar : El Salvador
properties.description: $925 of $1,150 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 20, 2011 Oscar is 53 years old. He lives with his life partner and his son who attends a school near their town. Oscar's business is a garage, body shop and paint shop. It is one of the busiest in the area because he offers good-quality work at very affordable prices. Oscar would like to see his business grow and he knows that when you want something you must run risks. For this reason, he believes that all the effort he puts into his work is worthwhile. This has driven him to request a loan from INTEGRAL which will give him the possibility to buy material for his work such as different colored paints, vehicle accessories, vehicle parts, oils and some tools. In this way, he will be able to keep his business ahead of the competition and provide his household with financial security and his family with a full life.

properties.title: Patricia Makaa : Kenya
properties.description: $425 of $575 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Patricia is a 28-year-old businesswoman who is a single mother of two children ages six and eight. For the past four years, she has been selling clothing. She earns a monthly income of 18,000 KES which she uses to provide for her children’s needs. Patricia is applying for her second loan with KADET to purchase new clothing for her shop to increase the variety of merchandise she provides to her clients. She has successfully repaid her previous loan. Patricia will use the anticipated profits from her loan to educate her children and expand her business. In the future, she hopes to open a wholesale shop.

properties.title: Arus Isayan : Armenia
properties.description: $2,825 of $3,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 1, 2011 Arus is engaged in farming. She keeps cattle and pigs. Arus is married and lives with her husband, their child and husband’s parents. The couple is planning to expand their family, and to insure a stable future for the children and the grownups, Arus would like to increase her income through expanding the business. With this loan, Arus will buy more livestock.

properties.title: Maria Martha Yauqui Ushca : Ecuador
properties.description: $150 of $800 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Maria Martha is 30 years old and a single mother. She lives with her mother and her children in the canton of Guaranda in Bolívar Province. The members of the Sacred Heart Communal Bank meet in the sector of Cuatro Esquinas, which is part of the canton of Guaranda and located 15 minutes from the office of Cooperativa San Jose. The Communal Bank consists of 12 members who engage in agriculture, livestock breeding, the sale of their products, and other profitable activities. Maria is a farmer who grows potatoes, wheat, and corn. She also has two heads of cattle. Maria purchases her supplies at the market in Guaranda and sells her products at the wholesale market in the same city. She is requesting a loan to buy supplies for her crops. With the financial assistance provided through this loan, she will be able to acquire needed supplies. The challenges she faces include diseases that could impact her crops. Her dreams include having her own house and land so that she can continue planting. Maria enjoys the Carnival festivities.

properties.title: Teresita Barroca : Philippines
properties.description: $250 of $425 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 1, 2011 As a widowed parent of six children, Teresita works hard to support her family. She has a general store business in the Philippines and also earns additional income from raising livestock. Teresita is borrowing PHP 18,000 through NWTF to buy items like shampoo, groceries, etc. to sell in her general store. Teresita has been sustaining her business activities through her past nine loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream: to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

properties.title: Bilal : Jordan
properties.description: $1,675 of $1,700 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 10, 2011 Bilal, a 41-year-old married father of three children from Marka, Jordan, has a garage where he repairs vehicles. Bilal is requesting a loan of 1200JD to improve his garage. He is looking forward to increasing his income and improving his family's living conditions.

properties.title: Naseem's Group : Pakistan
properties.description: $375 of $1,425 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 28, 2011 Naseem is a housewife, preferring to stay at home and do her household work. Her husband is a carpenter and also operates a scrap business. He makes furniture on order. He is very skillful in his work and has got a good reputation among his clients for his quality work. His scrap business also earns him good profit every month. He sells scrap to different factories and other scrap dealers. Naseem has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s businesses. With the loan, her husband will buy wood and nails and also used paper and plastic bottles for both his businesses so that he earns well from them and generates the maximum profit. Naseem hopes that her husband’s hard work and the loan investment will bring positive financial changes to his businesses and her family will be able to enjoy a better living standard as a result. Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Naseem.

properties.title: Assurance Group : Benin
properties.description: $900 of $2,500 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 1, 2011 Assurance is a group of fifteen members, and its president is named Mariam. The group members live in the same neighborhood in Benin. In order to increase their working capital, the group is seeking its first loan through Alidé. Born in 1961 in Benin, Mariam lives with her husband and children in a city in Benin. Her husband Djawara is a farmer, and her children are all in school. Mariam and her husband pay the family's expenses jointly. For fifteen years Mariam has been selling rechargeable phone cards from her home. This business generates revenue which helps her pay some of the family's expenses. She buys her products at one of Benin's markets. This first loan will surely allow Miriam and other members of the Assurance group to expand their businesses and increase their client bases and revenues.

properties.title: Karibu View Group : Tanzania
properties.description: $3,525 of $4,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 5, 2011 Mwajabu, who is in her late 30s, is married with two children who are going to school. She has had a business selling clothes for 10 years now. She works from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. daily and she is able to make a good monthly profit. This will be her fourth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to increase the clothes sales and also for a poultry business. She has paid back her loans successfully. She hopes for a loan so she can start distributing her clothes upcountry. Her dream is to one day be an international businesswoman. She will share this loan with her loan group "Karibu View" which has a total of 15 members who will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

properties.title: Kotognogontala 1 Group : Mali
properties.description: $1,475 of $1,875 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 1, 2011 The 10 members of the Kotognogontala group are married women averaging 38 years of age, with four children, and living for the most part in polygamous families in Fachoribougou, a village in the community of Kaboila, prefecture of Sikasso (the third administrative region of Mali). They collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiniwaso in order to ensure success of their agricultural activities during the winter season. They are on their eighth loan with the institution. Past loans have been duly reimbursed. They cultivate tomatoes and "jakatou" [a vegetable belonging to the eggplant family], as, for example, Fanta does. She is the first one standing on the right in the photo. With this loan she plans to pay the costs of manual labor, buy agricultural inputs and seeds in order to cultivate 2 hectares [5 acres] of land. The produce is sold in their village as well as at the market of Sikasso, to a customer base composed of both men and women. She plans to achieve a monthly income of 145,500 per agricultural cycle. This income will allow her to pay her loan and to help her husband with everyday expensive. She would like to continue this collaboration with Soro Yiriwas on order to cultivate a larger plot and increase her income.

properties.title: Sokheang Yarn : Cambodia
properties.description: $600 of $800 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Sokheang is a 42-year-old kindergarten teacher. Her husband is a chief of construction workers. Their income is approximately $5.50 per day. They have 5 children, 3 of whom are studying, while the other two work as construction workers. Every month, she spends roughly $100 on food, $30 on school fees, and $22 on other expenses. She would like to request a loan in the amount of $800 to repair her kitchen and build a toilet so that their family can live more comfortably. She explains that she has worked as a kindergarten teacher for about 10 years and that she never wants to change jobs or start a new career; besides, she hopes to earn more money just by working hard so that she can support the rest of her children with their studies until they secure good jobs in the future.

properties.title: John Muturi : Kenya
properties.description: $625 of $925 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 John is 47 years old and married to Jacinta. They are blessed with three children. John runs a carpentry business in Githurai 45. He has been doing this business for the past four years and gets an income of 16,000 KES. He has a good credit history with KADET and he is applying for his second loan of 80,000 KES from KADET LTD, which he plans to purchase more stock. He will use the anticipated profit to expand his business and educate his children. John hopes to expand his business. He is very hardworking.

properties.title: Dolgor Dovchin : Mongolia
properties.description: $575 of $800 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 5, 2011 Dolgor is 47 years old and lives with her husband and two daughters in a house in Hovd province of Mongolia. Her older daughter is a student while her husband works as a construction worker at a private company. Dolgor manages a fruit trading business at a rented stall at a trading center. She started her business in 2000 and is planning to continue it in the future. With her business earnings, she has been able to buy land where she is planning to build a house, in the future. She is a polite woman who attributes her business success to her good accounting skills. She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase fruits for her business.

properties.title: Julie Fermalan : Philippines
properties.description: $250 of $700 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Julie works hard to support her family. Julie is married and sells agricultural and veterinary products in the Philippines. Julie explains that she has been in this business for 2 years now. Julie is requesting a loan in the amount of 30,000 PHP through NWTF to buy additional stocks of agricultural and veterinary products for her business. In the future, Julie would like to save money to expand her business.

properties.title: Rubí Alvarado De Valles : Peru
properties.description: $750 of $800 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 4, 2011 Ms. Rubí is a member of the "Mujeres Solidarias" ("Women's Solidarity") communal bank in the district of Caleria, department of Ucayali. She is 50 years old, married, and has four children. She has been working with loans from Manuela Ramos for three years. She works sewing and making garments. She has a well-equipped workshop with four sewing machines, two of which are industrial. She will buy the following with her new loan of 2,200 nuevos soles: 15 kilograms of cotton fabric, 12 bobbins of thread in various colors, 1/2 a liter of machine oil, and four needle cloths (one for each machine) Her husband is an independent worker and they have had to work a great deal to be able to bring enough money into their house. This is why they both need to work to meet their family's needs. Her children are still small and need their parents' attention. Rubí is happy because now if she has the tools she can work and create good products.

properties.title: Kibiga Abamwe Group : Uganda
properties.description: $975 of $1,125 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Thirty years is the time it has taken 65-year-old Allan to obtain his footing in a competitive farming enterprise in Ntungamo in Western Uganda. The good humored, enterprising and resolute father of eight says so far the experience of engaging in this kind of business has been fulfilling. He began as a small-scale subsistence farmer, but it soon occurred to him that he could make significant ends meet by selling staple crops such as bananas, coffee, maize and millet, all of which command high prices in the food markets in most parts of Western Uganda. Once that thought took hold, Allan made painstaking arrangements to set forth in this business, purchasing more banana stems, maize and millet seeds to plant. Upon harvesting, he was able to transport his foods for sale in nearby food markets, earning a monthly income of 80,000 shillings At length, Allan has seen the rewards of this business and he remains ever-determined to solidify his niche in the food markets. To do this, he knows he has to further improve and modernize his farming gardens. Allan reckons this will come to fruition upon receiving this Kiva loan, with which he intends to purchase higher grade manure and mulches to apply on his farms. This, he is hoping, will go a long way toward improving the fertility of his farms, thereby improving his yields.

properties.title: Carolina Tocay Subuyuj De Joaquin : Guatemala
properties.description: $350 of $675 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 2, 2011 CAROLINA Carolina needs a second loan to buy gifts because Mother’s Day is celebrated in the month of May and she wants to vary her sales with balloon and floral arrangements because her business is located in the center of the village and is quite sought after on these dates. She also wants to invest another part in the tortilla sales she does at home. She wants to buy corn, firewood and also a griddle and she’d like to be able to earn extra income selling "granizadas" (shaved ice treats) outside her house. Her greatest wish is to always continue to grow in her various sales as well as raise her children who still go to local schools.

properties.title: Efua Tawiah : Ghana
properties.description: $175 of $275 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 3, 2011 Efua is married and has 2 children. She sells rice, tomatoes, groundnut and salted fish at Elmina, which she has done for 12 years. Her husband is a farmer. Efua assists her husband in the payment of school fees. She will use the loan to purchase additional salted fish to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Efua plans to save towards the university education of her children.

properties.title: Palo Herrado Ii Group : Honduras
properties.description: $475 of $650 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 6, 2011 Liliam, Ana Rosa, and Santos, all of whom reside in the Choluteca region of Honduras, formed the “Palo Herrado” solidarity group in June, 2011. Liliam has worked as a seamstress for several years and produces uniforms for a number of local schools. Liliam is requesting a loan of Lps. 4,000 to purchase fabric, thread, buttons, and zippers that will be used in her seamstress business. Ana Rosa runs a small chicken farm and Santos runs a small business selling new clothing.

properties.title: Safa : Palestine
properties.description: $875 of $2,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 23, 2011 Safa is a young mother of two daughters and two sons. Her husband Rafat is a National Palestinian authority employee who had to find another source of income besides his work. Safa's husband started buying charcoal in bulk to sell to stores in the city. Safa's husband's charcoal work is bringing him a good income. Therefore, he wanted to purchase a transportation car in order to start distributing to stores outside the city and gain more customers, Safa took out a loan from FATEN for this purpose. Safa is a conservative woman. Therefore, her husband is photographed instead.

properties.title: Juan Sosa : Paraguay
properties.description: $650 of $875 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 26, 2011 Juan is married to Nancy with whom he has 2 children, now at university age. He says that by means of his hard work, he was able to make possible his children's university education. One of his children, the woman, is finishing her university career with a Licenciate in Nursing, and the male is qualifying for the National Police. Both of these career tracks have an elevated cost and Juan paid for them by arduous work at the brick ovens. The couple holds title to their house and land. They now have 2 horses and a yoke of oxen. They can also count on a small car for transporting materials. Juan is requesting a loan to buy primary materials for making ceramic bricks. His dream is that some day he may get a truck for transport with a larger capacity.

properties.title: Malikahan Kaharova's Group : Kyrgyzstan
properties.description: $825 of $900 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 26, 2011 Malikahan, 56, is the leader of this group. She has been a self-starter since early childhood. In this way she found the talent of sewing in herself. An unending interest in fabric and new ways of design pushed her to pursue a profession as a seamstress and a fashion designer. Since all of her kids are already grown and live separately, Malikahan says she can devote herself fully to the business. The entrepreneur designs bedding for traditional Kyrgyz families. They include quilts called “kurpa”, “tushak” and pillows of different sizes and designs. She graduated from a technical college and knows how education is important in the development of a person. The business started with an initial capital of 500 soms and now brings 1,300 soms monthly. Malikahan applied for a loan because she needs to purchase materials for sewing national souvenirs. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

properties.title: Anonymous : Sierra Leone
properties.description: $75 of $1,150 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 30, 2011 The borrower is 45 years old. She is married and has 4 children ages 4, 6, 9 and 15 years old. In 1997, she established her provisions (milk, sardine, margarine, sugar etc.) business. She began her business because she wanted to generate income and establish a savings account. Working 6 days a week and 10 hours a day, she earns about 850,000 SLL every month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of 5,000,000 SLL. She requires a loan in order to add to capital to her business. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately 200,000 SLL. In the future, she plans to visit pilgrimage land (Mecca), continue to support her husband, and construct a house. Transportation and frequent increase in the cost of stocks are her biggest challenges. She thanks you for your support.

properties.title: Ephata Group : Mexico
properties.description: $1,900 of $2,375 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 4, 2011 This group is called "Ephata," which means "the smallest one." They are all looking for an opportunity to make more sales and to grow. They are located in the state of Mexico. The group is comprised of 10 members and this is the first time they are requesting a loan. Vilgahi is one member of the group. She is 48 years old, studied until the fifth year of primary school, is a homemaker, and has five children (two girls and three boys). She makes and sells tlacoyos (which consist of a thick, long oval tortilla prepared from a dough of corn and cooked beans, which can then be filled with various ingredients like beans, lima beans, meat, and cottage cheese). She started doing this ten years ago. She is requesting a loan to buy ingredients and supplies like corn, beans, pork rinds, and gas. Her customers are people in her area who prefer to buy her products for their quality and the good service and friendly attention she provides. At the moment, Vilgahi feels very happy to have the opportunity to invest and to distribute her product. Her business is important because with it, she can get ahead on her family's expenses and therefore have a better quality of life. She longs to give her daughter, who is currently in high school, the opportunity to pursue a professional career so that she can have a better future.

properties.title: Jean Paul : Rwanda
properties.description: $750 of $1,025 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 4, 2011 Jean Paul is 27 years old and is single. He has owned a store business selling various goods such as cooking oil, bags, kitchen utensils, etc. for the past two years. His business is well-organized and open daily from 7 a.m. until 7 p.m. Jean Paul has requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to buy various goods such as cooking oil, bags, kitchen utensils, lotions, soap, etc. to sell. With the profits, he plans to reinvest in his business and to save for his future.

properties.title: Widad : Lebanon
properties.description: $1,200 of $1,800 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 3, 2011 Widad is a 39-year-old married woman living in Ain with her husband. She opened a bakery to help her husband to cover their expenses and to improve their living conditions. Widad works hard to improve her business. She has requested a loan from Al Majmoua, a Kiva partner, for the third time, in order to buy flour and other necessary baking materials for the business. Widad is a borrower of good standing. Her customers are relatives, neighbors, and friends. She's honest and a woman who provides good customer service. She hopes to expand her business and to continue providing healthy living for her family. Widad operates her shop from her home; in that way she takes good care of both family and business at the same time.

properties.title: Larisa Margaryan : Armenia
properties.description: $1,025 of $1,350 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 30, 2011 Larisa is 51 years old. She lives in Ddmashen village, Sevan area, with her big family, which consists of her husband, her mother-in-law, her son, daughter-in-law and two grandchildren. Larisa has worked at the illuminating glass factory for 7 years. In the early nineties, Larisa started to engage in the agricultural business. On her farm she has cows, sheep, pigs and chickens. Larisa's family helps her with farming. They breed their animals and sell agricultural products to the villagers. Thanks to their occupation, Larisa and her family are able to support each other. This is Larisa's third loan from Nor Horizon and now she is asking for a 500,000 AMD loan to add to her sheep number and to buy fodder.

properties.title: Thamer Mnajjel : Iraq
properties.description: $1,625 of $1,800 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 30, 2011 This borrower is from Iraq. He is 29 years old, married and has three children. Thamer has owned a farm for rearing calves and cows since 2000. He has a long experience in this field and has a deep understanding of local consumer needs and he is well known in his area. He is requesting an $1800 loan to make an external fence. He is aiming to earn more profits to improve his family’s quality of life.

properties.title: Ana Cecilia : Ecuador
properties.description: $700 of $1,100 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 5, 2011 Ana Cecilia is 24 years old and lives in the city of Pimampiro in northern Ecuador. She is married and and lives with her husband and two children. Her daughter is six years old and her son is two years old. She is an entrepreneurial woman who is very dedicated to her family and her home. Ana Cecilia owns a store which she opened with the desire to progress economically while working in a place where she could be with her children. She is obtaining this loan for the purpose of expanding her business. She intends to increase the amounts of products she has available for her customers. She has been getting loans from FODEMI for five years to support her business. In the past, her loans have given her family many economic opportunities. In the future, she wants to continue progressing with her family and her business. In the photo, Ana Cecilia appears with her son and one of her customers.

properties.title: Felix Pedro Potosme : Nicaragua
properties.description: $225 of $275 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 22, 2011 Señor Félix Pedro is a working man and entrepreneur, 55 years of age, who has been dedicated for 15 years to the sale of plantain leaves, which are used generally for making tamales, nacatamales (a steamed corncake), yoltamal (Nicaraguan corn tamales) and to serve vigoron (a Nicaraguan dish made with cabbage, onions, tomatoes, chile, yucca and fried pork), chancho (seasoned fried pork) with yucca, vaho (dish made with meat, green plantains and yucca cooked in plantain leaves)...etc. He will invest the loan in the purchase of plantain leaves to continue growing his business.

properties.title: Kotognogontala 7 Group : Mali
properties.description: $525 of $1,375 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 1, 2011 The ten members of the Kotognogontala 7 Group are married women, on average 37 years old, with four children, who mostly live in polygamist families in Fachoribougou, a village in the district of Kaboila in the Sikasso prefecture, the third administrative region of Mali. They are working with the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, in order to better manage their agricultural business during the winter season. They are on their eighth loan with the institution; all prior loans have been fully repaid. Aminata, the first woman on the left of the photo, in the front row, primarily grows tomatoes and jakatou- a type of small green eggplant. With this loan, she intends to pay labor wages, purchase agricultural inputs and seeds to tend a 1 hectare plot. After the harvest, the produce is sold in the village and in the market of Sikasso, to a clientele of men and women. She intends to earn an average profit of 65,500 FCFA per year. This profit will allow her to payback her loan and also to help her husband with household expenses. She hopes to maintain this relationship with Soro Yiriwaso in order to work an even larger plot in order to draw more profits.

properties.title: Rumichaka Group : Peru
properties.description: $3,400 of $3,500 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 6, 2011 The Communal Bank “Rumichaka” is starting its ninth cycle with 16 members. They engage in agriculture, planting vegetables, and other activites. However, they were affected by the constant rains that occurred throughout the area during the months of January and February of this year. Nelly is serving as President for this current loan cycle. She is 24 years old, in a common-law marriage, and has three children (ages 9, 5, and 3). Nelly grows vegetables and plants. The loan she is requesting will be invested in the purchase of vegetable seeds. Nelly grows vegetables in the community of Rumichaka, which is 25 minutes away from the city of Huamanga. During the harvest season, she brings her produce to the Nery García Zarate Market to sell in bulk. She joined FINCA Peru after being invited by the other members and is now participating in her second loan cycle. She enjoys the convenience of the loans and the great joy that comes when finishing a loan cycle. Nelly already has a little bit of money saved. Her dream is to recover from the rains that impacted her farmland so that her business can continue to prosper.

properties.title: Sonia Carolina : El Salvador
properties.description: $275 of $400 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 24, 2011 Sonia lives with her family: her mother and her two children. She owns her own home. Sonia is a saleswoman who sells clothes, shoes and accessories. She set up her business two years ago, on her own initiative and with her mother's support. She does not work fixed hours. Sonia needs a loan to buy a range of shoes and clothes for both sexes. This investment will help her to have better styles of shoes, blouses, skirts and shorts available. This will enable her to better serve her customers. Sonia's goal is to set up her own company that is more profitable so that she can guarantee better comfort for her family.

properties.title: Sarouen Hout : Cambodia
properties.description: $75 of $1,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Fifty-year-old Sarouen and her husband fish for a living, earning a combined income of $4.6 per day. They have three children, one a factory worker earning $3 per day and the other two students. Every month, Sarouen has to spend $80 on food, $15 on electricity, and $10 on school fees. If she can save more money, she expects to buy a new boat to replace their old one. Sarouen is now requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase a motorbike for her daughter's commute to work and for other family use as well. She has a strong commitment to send her other two children to university to study.

properties.title: Merlinda Olmodo : Philippines
properties.description: $200 of $450 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 2, 2011 As a married parent of seven children, Merlinda works hard to support her family. She has a food stall business in the Philippines and also earns additional income from a general store. Merlinda is borrowing PHP 19,000 through NWTF to buy more stock to sell in her food stall business. Merlinda has been sustaining her business activities through her past 15 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

properties.title: Maria Maricela Moncada : Honduras
properties.description: $75 of $1,075 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Maria lives in the town of El Paraiso in southern Honduras, where she has run a small beauty salon for the past six years. Her shop enjoys steady business due to its central location in the town center. Maria is requesting a loan of 20,000 Honduran lempira (HNL) to purchase supplies such as shampoos, conditioners, and dyes for her salon. This will be her second loan with Prisma, and she had a punctual payment record over the course of her first loan.

properties.title: Riziki Majaliwa : Kenya
properties.description: $325 of $450 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 25, 2011 Riziki is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. She operates a charcoal selling business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge with the high cost of transportation in her business. She dreams of establishing a retail shop in the future. With the 40,000 KES she wants to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

properties.title: Mabel Koomson : Ghana
properties.description: $175 of $275 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 3, 2011 As shown in the photo, Mabel sells different types of cloth, slippers, etc. at Elmina. She has been through senior high school. She is married and has two children. Her husband is into carpentry. She has been selling cloth, slippers, etc. for five years. She assists her husband in the payment of household expenses. Her loan will be used to buy more cloth to sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to build a shop.

properties.title: Yao Eric : Togo
properties.description: $675 of $875 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 5, 2011 Yao Eric is 33 years old. He is a driver by profession and repairs cars. This is his first loan and he is seeking this sum in order to buy tools for his work. He gets his supplies at the independent port in Lomé. His wife is a retailer and they have three children. Yao Eric's primary objective is to improve the social circumstances of his family.

properties.title: C4711 Tujyeheza Group : Rwanda
properties.description: $1,550 of $1,700 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 1, 2011 Alexandre is 36 years old and is married with seven children between the ages of 2 and 14. He is the representative of a group called "Tuyjeheza" in the local language. Alexandre is the first person on the right who is raising his hand. He has been in this business for one year. His business is well-organized, and he is open from 8am until 5pm every day and employs one person to help him. Alexandre and his group have requested a loan from Kiva lenders in order to purchase more quantities of fruits and vegetables to sell. He will reinvest the profits in his business and save for his family.

properties.title: Anonymous : Lebanon
properties.description: $825 of $1,200 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 10, 2011 This Kiva borrower is a 31-year-old Lebanese married man. He is living with his wife and two school-age children. He has owned a barber shop since 2008. He is well known in the whole region for his good business reputation and great customer service. In parallel, during the school year, he works as a driver transporting students from their houses to school and vice versa. He works hard in both jobs to be able to cover the heavy life expenses. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase added products needed for his barber shop. He will also purchase a wax machine in order to satisfy his customer’s demands. In the future, he is planning to expand his business into other areas.

properties.title: Ilva Del Carmen Diaz Garcia : Nicaragua
properties.description: $150 of $900 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 23, 2011 Ilva is married. Her husband works as a driver and helps her with expenses. Her children are in school and her short term goals are that her children become professionals. She is a very hard working woman who has a grocery store. She started it a long time ago with her own funds. Her future plans are to expand the business with larger amounts of merchandise in order to obtain larger benefits. She will use the loan to buy groceries like basic grains, cleaning accessories and fruit, among other products that are much in use among Nicaraguan families.

properties.title: Doris Elizabeth : El Salvador
properties.description: $200 of $500 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 25, 2011 Dora Elizabeth is 38 years old and lives at home with her husband and two children (ages 17 and 15) who are in school. She works hard so that she can help her family get ahead and provide them with what they need. Dora sells beauty products such as lotions, crèmes, shampoo, scented soaps, cosmetics, and other items. She operates her business as a traveling vendor in the area where she lives and in the surrounding areas. Dora has many customers because she is a friendly and honest woman. She always guarantees the quality of her products and offers a variety of merchandise at the best prices. Since she decided to increase the variety of products that she offers, her customers have more options from which to select or they can request the products that they want. Dora places her faith in God to see her business prosper, so she decided to request this loan from Apoyo Integral to buy a variety of cosmetics, lotions for men and women, crèmes, scented soaps, deodorants, and other items. She hopes this loan will help her improve her quality of life and provide her children a different path than the one she has taken.

properties.title: Onesmus Mutuku Mutinda : Kenya
properties.description: $200 of $225 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 30, 2011 Onesmus is 39 years old, married and has four children. For the last 18 years, he has earned a living making and repairing vehicle interiors. He has applied for this loan to buy more supplies and tools for his business. His goal is to use his profits to pay for his children’s education and improve their standard of living. In the future, he would like to keep expanding his business. Onesmus describes himself as hardworking, humble and friendly.

properties.title: Neli Gumende : Mozambique
properties.description: $350 of $550 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Neli is from the district of Matutuine in Maputo province. She went to school through the ninth grade. She works on Ouro Sul beach and has a five-year-old son. Neli currently lives and works in the popular tourist destination Ponta d'Ouro in Matutuine. She uses her salary and the profits from her business to support her family and even save a little in the Banco Comercial (BCI). She heard about Hluvuku-Adesma through conversations with her siblings, who are Hluvuku-Adesma clients, and decided to approach the organization to find out more about how to become a client and to take advantage of the loans to carry out her projects. Neli became a Hluvuku-Adesma client for the first time this year, and is requesting a loan in the amount of 15,000 meticals to purchase goods (25-kg and 10-kg sacks of rice, beer, soft drinks, etc.). She wants to see her business grow and finish building her house, and will look to Hluvuku-Adesma for more financing.

properties.title: Euphrasie : Benin
properties.description: $700 of $1,100 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 1, 2011 Born in Benin on March 9, 1951, Euphrasie is married to a man named Thomas. The couple has four children, two of whom still depend on them. All the children attend school. The couple provides for the various needs of the household together. Euphrasie only attended primary school. To support herself and her family, Euphrasie has been selling fabrics and outfits (for gentlemen and ladies) for almost twenty years. Euphrasie purchases her products in Benin and Togo, a neighbor country to Benin. She retails clothing in her shop and sometimes through the distribution system. In order to increase her level of activity and to better satisfy her customers' needs, Euphrasie is requesting for the first time ALIDé's financial support.

properties.title: Jorge Mario Tabares Agudelo : Colombia
properties.description: $275 of $850 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 3, 2011 Raising pigs to sell is the family’s traditional occupation because Jorge Mario is a farmer from Titiribí in Antioquia. He learned farming chores alongside his father while still a little boy. His business is his source of support for this entrepreneur, his wife and their two children. Jorge currently needs a loan to pay for some pigs he acquired recently and to buy feed that will make it possible for him to fatten them up more quickly and generate income to improve his and his family’s quality of life.

properties.title: Naziran's Group : Pakistan
properties.description: $1,050 of $1,250 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 28, 2011 Naziran is married. She is very simple lady and keeps herself busy in household work and taking care of her family. She is fond of cooking and makes healthy food for her family. Her husband is involved in an animal sales business. He buys young animals like goats and cows and raised them for sale. He has been operating this business for many years. He loves his business and by seeing him practice it, Naziran also started helping him by taking care of his cattle. She can now give them timely food and water and clean their stall. Her husband’s business grows greatly at the Eid (Muslim holiday) when people come to him to buy animals for slaughter. At other times, he sells them to butchers and earns income for the family. Naziran has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further expansion of her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy goats for resale. She hopes that the loan investment will be a productive one for him.

properties.title: Taghreed Sowan : Jordan
properties.description: $525 of $1,275 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 4, 2011 Taghreed is a 31-year-old single lady who started a clothes retail business at her home six years ago. Over these six years, Taghreed was able to open her own boutique in a busy area that customers can easily get to. Even her prices are very convenient, according to what her customers say. Now Taghreed has applied for a loan to add new clothing models that go with the fashion these days and of course that suit most people's tastes, so she can raise her income and open another branch in the future.

properties.title: Arlene Caballero : Philippines
properties.description: $100 of $250 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Arlene is 32 years old and married. She has one child. Arlene works hard to provide for her family. She runs a variety store in the Philippines. She has been running the variety store for two years and also earns an income from raising pigs. She has requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional stocks of items like soft-drinks, biscuits and candies to sell in her variety store. Arlene has borrowed and repaid two loans from NWTF before this loan. Arlene aspires to save enough money so she can send her child to college and expand her business.

properties.title: Qakhraman Akhmadov : Azerbaijan
properties.description: $1,100 of $1,400 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 21, 2011 Qakhraman is a responsible father and loving husband. While young, he learned the honorable work of raising livestock from his parents and that is how he earns a living today. Thanks to his valuable knowledge of livestock, he has been able to obtain good results from his business. This enterprising gentleman’s wish is to invest more capital in young animals. He hopes to continue his dedication to his work, and believes that by improving his stock and feed, his cattle will bring better prices. Three previous loans from AqroInvest helped Qakhraman to build his business step by step and reap success from each loan. For this reason, he is turning to you for financial support that will permit him to continue developing his business.

properties.title: Kholisakhon Abdulloeva : Tajikistan
properties.description: $1,025 of $1,075 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 27, 2011 An honest and hardworking woman, Kholisakhon has been processing dried fruit for three years, assisted by her family. In season she purchases about 6000-6500 kg of fresh fruits and after processing gets 1200 kg of dried fruit and 600 kg of ossicles (pits). From profits earned last year she purchased furniture for her house. Kholisakhon is now requesting a loan of 5000 TJS to purchase fresh apricots for processing. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes its role as a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

properties.title: 27 De Mayo Group : Bolivia
properties.description: $875 of $2,950 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 27, 2011 The May 27th Communal Bank is starting its third loan cycle with Pro Mujer as part of the Copacabana Community Center. This group consists of 10 members and is led by a Board of Directors headed by Sra. Susana. The members of the Communal Bank engage in different business such as selling “api” (a breakfast beverage made from corn), sewing, selling food, weaving, selling livestock, selling freeze-dried potatoes, and selling pork. Sra. Susana says she joined Pro Mujer a year and a half ago after being invited by a promoter. She currently manages a business selling “api” that she started 10 years ago. Susana learned this trade from her mother. The loan she is receiving now will be used to buy flour and sugar for making the pastries that are served with the “api”. She will buy her supplies at the Saturday fair in Batallas and then sell her products in La Paz. Working in this manner will generate income for Susana so that she can support her family. She is married and has four children. When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, Susana said that she enjoys the health services that are promoted through the organization’s wellness campaigns.

properties.title: Karambenor Group : Senegal
properties.description: $2,650 of $3,825 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 1, 2011 This solidarity group was created on June 7, 2011. It is made up of 36 women who live in the same village. Their primary activity is petty commerce. Madame Juliette, who is on the right in the photo raising her hand, is the leader of the group. She is 36, married, and the mother of six children. Her business is selling smoked fish. She has a good deal of experience in this field as she has been doing this work for several years. This loan will permit her to bolster her working capital and buy more merchandise (smoked fish) so that she can expand her little business. The profit she generates through her business will allow her to help improve living conditions for her family (health, food, clothing, etc.) and put aside more in savings.

properties.title: Mujeres Luchadoras Group : Paraguay
properties.description: $1,950 of $2,075 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 5, 2011 The group named "Mujeres Luchadoras", meaning "Overcoming Women", was formed through a union of several neighbors in the city of Mariano R. Alonso. All of the members of the group actively work in a cooperative environment and in a mutually respectful way. They came together with the goal of earning a better income for their households in order to provide their families with a decent life, not having to deprive themselves and they once had to. Rosa is one of the members of the group. She sells drinks from her home. She has had her business for some time, which is why she has a well established client base. She says that she gets the most business on the weekends and most often her merchandise is not enough to meet the demands. She dreams of expanding her business some day and to have a better inventory for her store. She requests a loan to purchase more drinks for her store, such as whisky, soft drinks, beer, energy drinks, juices, and others. She has her hopes set on getting a loan which will be a great source of help.

properties.title: Tholukuphila Group : South Africa
properties.description: $1,550 of $1,800 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Nonhle is 27 years old and married with 1 child that is 6 years old. She has been operating a retail shop for the last 4 months. From her home, she sells cell phone minutes, electricity vouchers, and women's handbags. She also receives a grant from the South African government to support her child. Nonhle hopes to expand her business but says that her biggest challenge are customers who take her stock on credit and refuse to pay on time. She thinks that the profits that she saves will help her send her child to college. In the photo she is standing on the far left with the blue and black shirt. She would like to thank WDB and Kiva for helping her life a lot.

properties.title: Nelly : Peru
properties.description: $925 of $1,100 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 29, 2011 Nelly is a member of the "Virgen Purificada - Angostura" community bank which is located in Cusco district, in Cusco province and department. Nelly is 31 years old, lives with her partner, and has one child. She divides her time between her daily activities and her business raising animals such as chickens and guinea pigs. She fattens the animals and then sells them in different markets. In addition, Nelly has a small minibus that provides a public service in the city of Cusco. Through these businesses, she gets her son ahead in life. Nelly would like to expand and improve both her animal business and her transport business. She is requesting this loan to buy animals such as chickens and guinea pigs and also to have maintenance work carried out on her vehicle. Nelly is happy to be receiving the loan and pledges to make her repayments on time.

properties.title: Iman : Lebanon
properties.description: $2,650 of $2,800 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 17, 2011 Iman, age 51, has owned and operated a grocery store since 1999. In addition to grocery items, she sells a number of gifts and gadgets, which she added to her inventory in order to increase her income. She lives in Tyre with her husband and two children. Iman is requesting a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua in order to increase her business capital by purchasing gift items and summer beverages to offer for sale. She also intends to use some of the profits from her loan funds to continue building her family house. This is Iman's second cycle as an Al Majmoua borrower. Her previous loan helped her to introduce new products to her business, and this investment helped to increase her income. Iman works hard on improving and expanding her business so that she can help to provide her family with the best possible standard of living.

properties.title: Valentina Galgo : Philippines
properties.description: $475 of $575 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 2, 2011 Valentina is 56 years old and single. She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Valentina is borrowing PHP 25,000 through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs. She has been raising pigs for 36 years, and also earns additional income from a sari-sari (general) store. She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to build and expand her business to secure a future for her family.

properties.title: Charles Karanja : Kenya
properties.description: $475 of $575 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 28, 2011 Charles has practiced farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last twenty one years. He is 42 years old, married to Lucy and they have eight school age children. He was introduced to KADET by one of our field officers and this will be his third loan. He paid all of his previous loans off and in good time. He plans to use the loan amount to buy potato seeds, fertilizer and spraying chemicals. He will sell his produce at the local market as he does small scale farming. In the future Charles hopes to buy more land and practice large scale farming in the Ndunyu Njeru area.

properties.title: Vicenta Lourdes : Bolivia
properties.description: $300 of $1,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 24, 2011 Vicenta’s activity is food sales, an activity she does only on weekends, specifically on Sundays. She prepares roasted piglet and roasted chicken. Her children and husband help her with this activity. The loan will be used to buy a larger oven and a fryer to increase production and be able to expand her snack bar. She makes very delicious dishes and is well known in the place for the good service she provides her customers. She’s a very hard working person who is grateful to the institution for the support provided.

properties.title: Bertha Morales : United States
properties.description: $6,075 of $6,575 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 4, 2011 Bertha’s inspiration for getting into the apartment business was her children and the knowledge that she was not meant to work for someone else her whole life. She chose to become a landlord because she felt that she could own this business, work full-time until it took a foothold, and still devote time to her three children. Bertha realized she wanted to own rental property while sitting on the porch of her rented apartment in Houston, Texas. As she looked at the ugly façade of her complex, she began to visualize the numerous ways in which the building could be improved. After a short time, she says, she had a crystal clear idea of how to turn the run-down complex into a beautiful, flourishing community. With this dream as her motivation, Bertha decided to take a courageous leap. With only her experience as a renter as her guide, she called her landlord to discuss purchasing the complex. Six months later, Bertha was the owner of Bertha’s Homes and landlord of a newly purchased community of apartments. The first thing she attended to, she says, were the immediate, smaller repairs needed on the five units in her complex. Now, she is beginning to hire companies to repair the larger, structural issues with the building such as the weak foundations and old windows. Raising a family, learning the ins and outs of a new business, and working a full-time job hasn’t been easy. Bertha has had to grapple with a system of building permits and city officials, which, at one point, threatened to condemn her buildings and bankrupt her business. She says that her biggest business success to date was convincing the city that she would make the needed repairs to bring the buildings up to code. With this loan, Bertha will pay for the repairs to the major structural problems with her building. Without it, she says, she would have lost her business because, though she had enough saved for the minor repairs, she could not afford to pay the companies she hired to do the larger, most necessary ones. Though she says that every cent from her day job as a cook at a restaurant turns into a new investment in her business, Bertha remains satisfied and happy with her decision to become a landlord. She advises others to not get discouraged and to keep on trying until you have reached your goals. Getting started is the most difficult part, she says, and “if a door doesn’t open, it is because it’s not the one that will lead you to success. That’s the way I look at it.”

properties.title: Rona Manojo : Philippines
properties.description: $425 of $700 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Rona is 36 years old, married and has one child. Rona works hard to provide for her family. She runs a variety store in the Philippines. She has been running the store for nine years and also earns an income from selling ready-to-wear clothing. She has requested a PHP 30,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more items to sell in her variety store. Rona has borrowed and repaid 18 loans from NWTF before this loan. Rona aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

properties.title: Vy Hing : Cambodia
properties.description: $725 of $1,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Vy, 52 years old, is a housewife. She is a single mother with four children. One is working in the factory, and her son is a motor taxi driver. They can make $11 per day for their income. Every month, she has to spend $100 on food, $20 on transportation, $15 on electricity and $20 on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of $1,000 to buy a motorbike for another son who is also a motor taxi driver. In the future she would like to have a tailoring shop at her house if her children can help with the expense, because every expense in the family is dependent on three of her children.

properties.title: Rosa Maria Mendoza Rivera : Peru
properties.description: $500 of $550 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 1, 2011 Rosa is 32 years old, single, and lives in her parents' home. The only service the house receives is electricity. It is located in the rural area of Tambogrande district, in Piura department. This area is noted for its farming, livestock raising and handicrafts. Rosa sells beauty products through a catalog. Her business is located in her home but she has also been making sales door to door to her neighbors for several years. She sells products which help people to improve their personal image. Rosa also works for an NGO which is another source of income she has for covering her household needs. Rosa has requested a loan for 1,500 Peruvian soles from Edpyme Alternativa. She will use the money to buy a larger quantity of products that she will be able to continue offering to her customers. She will also buy furniture for displaying her products. With the income she makes from selling all her beauty products, Rosa will be able to repay her loan and improve her quality of life. Rosa is very well known as a hard-working, cheerful and responsible woman whose only goal is to continue doing well in life.

properties.title: Marleni Martinez Baca : Colombia
properties.description: $275 of $625 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Marleni lives in Los Cedros neighborhood, in the town of Soledad, with her three children who are between the ages of 14 and 21. Marleni dreams of working hard so that she can lay the foundations for a prosperous future for her children. She has a business selling general merchandise such as clothes, footwear, bags and household products which she delivers to salespeople in the center of Barrnquilla. She provides the goods on credit and collects payment on the weekend. Marleni has been working with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo for 16 years and has received 12 loans. She invested them all very well and managed to increase her working capital and also significantly increase her income, thereby improving her family's well-being. Her main achievement is that, through her persistent work, she has managed to provide her children with an education. This Kiva loan is Marleni's 13th loan and she will use it to buy jeans, footwear, cold meats, sweaters and cologne which she has orders for. Through this investment, she plans to continue increasing her working capital, putting all her efforts into strengthening her business and making it sustainable. Her business profitability is no less than 43%.

properties.title: Los Tulipanes 1 & 2 Group : Dominican Republic
properties.description: $1,075 of $3,075 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 27, 2011 Giorgina is the coordinator of her group, Los Tulipanes 1 & 2 (tulips). This is a group composed of 15 business women. All of them are working to improve their lives and their familys' also. They live in one of the poorest areas around Santo Domingo city, a large community called Los Alcarrizos, which is located at the north of the city.
