Giorgina makes her home here in a simple structure with her long-term partner and their two children. Giorgina is excited to be seeking her third loan with Esperanza. She successfully paid off her previous loan after using it to make a successful investment in her "Colmado" (a small grocery store, located in neighborhoods where people go to buy mostly daily meals). She plans to use this loan to invest in her business by buying goods like rice, beans, vegetables, cooking oil, canned products, sugar, coffee, etc. She provides in her business all the products a family might need to cook. Giorgina's dreams are to develop herself as businesswoman, with an improved business and sustainable life, together with her family. She thanks all of you for your support.

properties.title: Muhammad Ahmad : Palestine
properties.description: $725 of $1,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 22, 2011 Muhammad is a young man from Qalqilia- Palestine. He is married and a father of two sons. Muhammad runs an electronics store selling irons, hair dryers, mixers, etc. Muhammad wants to have a better income as the current one is barely enough, so he took out a loan from FATEN to redecorate his store so as to have the items exhibited in a better arrangement and attract more customers. Muhammad is photographed in FATEN's branch in Qalqilia.

properties.title: Catalina Hortencia Prudente De La Rosa : Ecuador
properties.description: $600 of $1,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 28, 2011 Catalina is 42 years old and lives in a peri-urban area, in El Fortín, Guayaquil. She is separated and has two children aged 23 and 13. One of her children is at university and the other is in high school. Catalina's business is selling meals. Catalina started her business ten years ago. She used to sell from a cart and then decided to open an eatery. She previously used to work as a cook in a restaurant. Catalina works in her eatery, preparing meals from 6.00am. One of the problems she has in her neighborhood is crime. One day some customers robbed her as they left her premises. With the help of this loan, Catalina would like to buy supplies for her eatery such as plates, fans and other items. In the future, she would like to set up a branch in another place so that she can expand and make more income. She would also like her daughter to finish university.

properties.title: Alia's Group : Pakistan
properties.description: $1,025 of $1,050 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 22, 2011 Alia is a caring & supportive lady by nature. She not only carries out her responsibilities as a housewife well but also operates her business selling bed sheets very efficiently. She does this work to support her husband financially. They both help each other to sustain their finances. Her husband also sells bed sheets and he sells rugs. He is a very hard worker. He puts the bed sheets on his bicycle everyday and sells by visiting different areas of the city. They both have no children yet. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her brother who also sells bed sheets and rugs. With the loan, he will buy bed sheets and rugs in larger quantity to be able to offer more variety to his customers and earn better profits. He has been doing this business for the past 10 years and Alia is hopeful that an investment will help him make better profits by improving his business. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her third loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained a good credit behavior and never missed any meetings.

properties.title: Sonia : El Salvador
properties.description: $550 of $800 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 28, 2011 Sonia, 51, lives in her own home with her two grown daughters. They help Sonia with her business, which is located in the same place as her residence. She sells drinks and she also makes tortillas that she sells outside of a supermarket that is close to her house. She also delivers the tortillas at lunchtime to the employees who work in the commercial area that surrounds the neighborhood where she lives. Sonia has had these businesses for a number of years, and it has been through this hard work that she has managed to provide for her daughters. Every day Sonia and her daughters get up very early. Sonia makes her purchases in the market close to her neighborhood, buying the supplies she needs to make the drinks, including ingredients for horchata (a drink made of rice, almonds and cinnamon), tamarind, melon, barley, and other items. Meanwhile, her daughters stay in the kitchen cooking the corn that they will later take to grind to prepare the delicious tortillas. Now Sonia has decided to buy the corn and sugar she needs to make her tortillas and drinks at wholesale. This way she can lower the cost of her ingredients and also have a greater quantity of both products on hand, because at this point her she does not have enough of these products. Sonia's customers prefer her business because of her hygiene, responsibility and friendliness. For all of these reasons she has decided to request a loan from INTEGRAL; she is confident that through this loan she will be able to have greater earnings and improve the quality of life of her family.

properties.title: Fatuma Mtundo : Kenya
properties.description: $275 of $550 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 30, 2011 Fatuma is a married woman who owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. Fatuma operates a retail shop business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. In addition she also operates a farming business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. With the Kshs 50,000 she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, rice and potatoes. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

properties.title: Makhmasharif Saidov : Tajikistan
properties.description: $225 of $1,100 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 19, 2011 Makhmasharif is married and the father of five children. He is a hard-working man. He has been running his business selling foods for seven years. He sells eggs, cakes, sweets and other daily products. Makhmasharif purchases his goods from the firms “Shirinohoi sharki” and “Shirin” from Khujand city 2-3 times a week. His son helps him in this business. Makhmasharif would like to get a loan of 5,000 TJS to purchase a new assortment of foods in order to expand his business and increase his working capital. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

properties.title: Jose Guillermo Barrantes Araya : Costa Rica
properties.description: $600 of $1,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 4, 2011 José Guillermo is 35 years old, married, and lives with his wife and two children who are his highest priorities. He intends to use this loan to buy construction tools. José is a home builder and wants his construction jobs to be completed well and be of good quality. He has some power tools, but in order to do a perfect job he needs to acquire the ones that he does not yet own. José wants to perform the best work for the people who hire him so that he can earn more income by completing better jobs. He thinks about the future of his wife and children and wants to provide them with a better quality of life. José also wants to move forward with the plans he has made for himself and his wife. This is the first loan he has received from FUDECOSUR. José has not had any previous loans with the state banks. FUDECOSUR is providing this loan with better terms and a lower interest rate.

properties.title: Diabandor Group : Senegal
properties.description: $1,775 of $2,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 1, 2011 This solidarity group was created on 27 April 2008. It comprises seven women who live in the same area. Their main activity consists of running small businesses. Ms. Siré, whose hand is raised on the right in the photo, is responsible for the group. She is 35 years old. She is married and has six children. She is active in selling peanut paste, dried fish, and palm oil. She has gained lots of experience in this field, which she has been involved in for eight years. This loan will allow her to increase her capital and better develop her business. The profits will allow her to improve her family's standard of living (health, nutrition, education, etc.) and increase her savings.

properties.title: Chin Mean : Cambodia
properties.description: $700 of $1,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Chin, 64 years old, is a farmer and sells hand grinding product. Her husband is a blacksmith. Their income is $15 per day. Every month, she spends $40 on food, $10 on transportation and $5 on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of $1000 to buy hand grinding product to sell. She does not want to have another career beside what she has now. This couple is getting older now, so they do not care to extend their business or repair the house anymore. They just want to have enough income to support their family's costs of living.

properties.title: Adwoa Agyeiwaa : Ghana
properties.description: $325 of $1,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 5, 2011 For the past 5 years, Adwoa has been selling slippers, sandals and materials. She is married and has 3 children. Her husband is a mason. She has been through senior high school. Adwoa, as part of her marital duties, assists her husband to pay utility bills. She will use the loan to purchase more of the goods mention above to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans to reinvest for further growth.

properties.title: Francoise : Rwanda
properties.description: $675 of $850 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 4, 2011 Francoise is 44 years old. She is married with six children who are between 6 and 17 years old. She sells items such as: cooking oil, juice, rice, bananas and so on. Her business is well-organized. She has been in this business for one year and she works from 6 am until 9 pm everyday except on Saturday. She currently employs one person to help her. To improve her business, Francoise has requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase more goods like: rice, bananas, books, water, cooking oil and juice to sell. With the extra profits, Francoise will reinvest in her business and save for her family's future.

properties.title: Eulogio : Bolivia
properties.description: $950 of $1,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 6, 2011 Eulogio is a longstanding client. Since the year 2007 he was in the “Leo” communal bank but now Eulogio is asking for a loan and this is his first sequence as an individual borrower. He will use it to buy angular metal rods and metal sheets to do his work. Eulogio has a metal shop where he does work with a lathe. He is very dedicated to his work and very responsible with his payments to Emprender. Eulogio lives in the Pampahasi zone. He is very happy to be chosen for a Kiva loan and grateful to the institution for the support provided.

properties.title: Leah Magbanua : Philippines
properties.description: $450 of $475 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 4, 2011 Leah is 43 years old and married. She has two children. Leah is in the agricultural business, farming rice in the Philippines. She has been farming rice for 20 years now and has borrowed six times in the past from NWTF to sustain it. Leah requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to buy fertilizer and other farm supplies. In the future, Leah would like to save enough to buy more farmland.

properties.title: Aura Luz Pinell Rayo : Nicaragua
properties.description: $750 of $825 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 5, 2011 Aura Luz is a fifty-year-old mother of two children, ages 18 and 20. For the last twenty-five years, Aura Luz has sold pork from pigs that she buys from breeders. She learned this business from her mother who originally started the business. With the loan proceeds, Aura Luz can buy a greater quantity of pigs. Her dream is to improve her living conditions and continue to grow her business.

properties.title: Blanca Irene : Mexico
properties.description: $225 of $1,025 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Blanca Irene lives in Llano Grande. She’s married and has two children in her care. They are: Crispín Alejandro, 15, and Abenair, 9. She requested the loan to buy ingredients to make milk-based candy as well as rennet tablets for the milk she uses to make cheese. She’s been in this line of work for 18 years and nine months and comments that she does well with it; she’s had good income and economic solvency. Her husband motivated her to get into this activity since he milks the cows and gathers the milk to make cheese; she decided to help him so that they can help each other out in this activity. Her greatest wish is that with the loan and cheese store to be able to get ahead and provide schooling for her young children who are growing up.

properties.title: Magoma Nezikokolima Group : Uganda
properties.description: $3,000 of $3,225 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 20, 2011 40 year old Buwembo has been in the construction business for 24 years now. Through these years, he says he has gone through the full mill of construction work and his confidence at succeeding in this type of business has always been sky high. In Mityana, like in many other areas in Uganda,the construction business is booming. This means people like Buwembo can get work on a regular basis. Buwembo is happily married with 6 kids and he says he began this business with the financial help of a close friend in Mityana town. Before that, he was engaged mostly in farming. He still finds time to do farming as it is a business from which he has been eking out side income. Per week, he says this business churns out 90,000 shillings as income. With this loan, Buwembo says he is going to purchase more land to do large scale farming.

properties.title: Sameiha Zeidan : Palestine
properties.description: $1,925 of $2,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 24, 2011 Sameiha is a 38-year-old wife and mother of two daughters and two sons. Sameiha's husband and oldest son, who appears in the picture instead of his conservative mother, work in the grocery store the family owns. Sameiha took out a loan from FATEN to prepare the other half of the store to be used for more goods and grocery items for sale. Sameiha's daughters and sons are school students.

properties.title: Tamaz Giunashvili : Georgia
properties.description: $125 of $1,225 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 5, 2011 Tamaz is a 62 year-old farmer from the village of Sasireti, Kareli District. Tamaz is married and lives with his wife, Maya, three sons (21, 19 and 8 years old) and a twenty-year old daughter. The only source of income for the family is farming. In particular, they have 5 hectares of farmland where wheat, barley, haricot beans, maize, cabbage, tomatoes, garlic and beets are grown. They also have a 3-hectare orchard with 500 apple, 350 peach and 20 cherry trees. Tamaz also has a tractor equipped with different attachments. He uses it on his own farm as well as on neighborhood farms, providing them with different types of services. That is an additional source of income for the family. Total average monthly income of the family is 600 Laris. Tamaz requested a loan to purchase fertilizers and insecticides for treating plants with parasites. Also, part of the loan will be used for paying workers who help the family. After fertilizing and treating the plants, Tamaz’s family will get a quality harvest and sell it for a good price. It will positively impact the income of the family. With the income, Tamaz plans to expand the farm by purchasing an additional 4 hectares of land for farming.

properties.title: Maria Elena Arroyo De Uscategui : Colombia
properties.description: $400 of $600 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 23, 2011 Maria Elena is a working woman who lives in the Cuidadela Cuarta Etapa area, where she has worked for 12 years in a business called "Sala de Belleza Mayito" (Beauty Salon). She is a professional stylist with many years of entrepreneurial experience. Regularly in her business she operates through a system at home with customers located in different neighborhoods of Barranquilla and Soledad. For most of her life she has lived in the Barranquilla neighborhood where her family still lives and where she gets most of her customers. Her home is composed of her spouse who is an independent taxi driver with his own vehicle, which generates significant revenue that supports the family expenditure and savings for contingencies of the vehicle. The balance sheet and the income of Maria's business shows the status of classic services that work at a low cost and manage accounts receivable due to beauty product sales, which she promotes when she provides advice on personal and professional image to customers. Their financial indicators show a stability in business and favorable conditions for investment, which she is going to achieve through this kiva loan. This is her first financing through the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo. This loan will be used to repair the chrome of the chairs, as well as to invest in beauty supplies and products for sale. Her goal is to increase her working capital in order to provide a comfortable service for her customers and generate more income to enhance the well-being of her home.

properties.title: Nicholas Kipkosgei : Kenya
properties.description: $200 of $575 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 26, 2011 Nicholas is 32 years old, married and supports a family of four. He has been in the farming business for the last ten years, with a monthly income of KES 5,000. With his fifth loan of KES 50,000 from KADET, he plans to purchase farm supplies for his family farm. This will help in timely land preparation. Nicholas' future plans are to continue with farming and improve his family's living standards economically.

properties.title: Alexander Vargas Corrales : Costa Rica
properties.description: $225 of $1,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Alexander is 45 years old, married, and lives with his wife and two children who are his highest priorities. He intends to use this loan to purchase necessary supplies for maintaining his coffee crop. Alexander has land that is suitable for growing this type of crop and wants to replant his coffee plantation so that he can increase production for next year. He thinks about the welfare of his wife and children and intends to improve his earnings by being successful with this coffee project. This is the first loan he has received from FUDECOSUR. Alexander has not had any previous loans with the state banks. FUDECOSUR is providing this loan with better terms and a lower interest rate.

properties.title: Anonymous : Peru
properties.description: $100 of $400 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 She is a member of the communal bank "Patron San Sebastian". The bank is located in the district of Cusco, belonging to the province of Cusco, and the department of Cusco. She is 36 years old, married, and she has 6 children. She alternates her daily activities with her office supply business. She sells notebooks, books, pencils and binders. She works from 7am to 6pm. It is through this business that she is able to provide for her children. She wants to expand her office supply business. She requests a loan to purchase merchandise in wholesale for her supply store. She is happy for her loan and she is committed to making her loan payments.

properties.title: Naim Reil : Cambodia
properties.description: $625 of $1,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Naim, 59 years old, is a farmer. She is a single mother with 3 children and she makes about $10 per day for her income. One of her children is studying, the other one is a hairdresser. Another of her children is working in Korea. Naim spends $38 on food, $13 on school fees, $7 on transportation and $10 on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of $1000 to buy corn seed and to hire workers to clear the grass on her plantation. Her career can make a good income that’s why she has never wanted to change it at all. For her future, she plans to grow cashew nuts instead of corn because it is easy for her when she gets older.

properties.title: Union Obregon Group : Mexico
properties.description: $2,325 of $2,350 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 30, 2011 This group is called "Union Obregon" because this is the name of the colony where they are located. It is in the Morelos state in Mexico. The group is made up of 8 members and this is the fourth time that they request a loan. Fabiola is a member of the group. She is 26 years old, attended through the third year of high school and is a merchant. She has 3 children, one girl and two boys. She sells umbrellas, a business that she started 6 years ago. She is requesting this loan to buy more umbrellas at wholesale, this way getting better pricing and different styles, sizes and colors. Since it is the rainy season, this is when she has the best sales. Her customers are happy because she provides a good variety of umbrellas and also reasonable prices. At the time of the loan request, she feels happy to be able to invest in her business. She wants the loan to buy merchandise and she will use the income that she obtains to enroll her children in school.

properties.title: Blanca Rosa Bayas Chimbo : Ecuador
properties.description: $750 of $1,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 5, 2011 Blanca Rosa is 22 years old and single. She lives with her parents in the Guaranda canton in the Bolívar province. The members of the Bellavista Communal Bank are located in the Papauco Pucara community, Guanujo parish, Guaranda canton. It is 15 minutes from Cooperative’s office. This communal bank is comprised of 11 members who devote themselves to agriculture, raising animals, and other business activities. Blanca grows potatoes, wheat, and corn. She makes her purchases at the Guaranda market. She sells at the wholesale market in the same city. She is requesting the loan to buy supplies for her crops. The support of the loan will help her financially so that she can fulfill her needs. She faces challenges like pest infestations, diseases, and climate changes. Her dream is to have a vehicle. She likes to take walks and celebrate holidays.

properties.title: Giselle Maria Moya Carrillo : Costa Rica
properties.description: $425 of $500 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 5, 2011 Doña Giselle is 49 years old. She is a very hard-working and striving woman with a great desire to have her own business. For the last 8 years, she has been working making confectionery and doing porcelain work. The señora also teaches on television's Channel 13 on the program "Mujeres del 2000" ("Women of 2000"). She lives with her husband and her child. This is the first time that she is requesting a loan through the foundation. With this loan, she plans to invest in the purchase of raw materials for making her products. The Señora has a small confectionery business; little by little and with the help of her husband, she has been able to obtain her working utensils, and with both their savings, they were able to buy the oven with which she works. Doña Giselle has had her confectionery business for 8 years. With the same techniques, she makes porcelain and gives classes on Channel 13. She is asking us for the loan for the purchase of raw materials to continue working, as porcelain is very expensive. In the kitchen in her home she has installed an oven for doing her work. The Señora has taken training in handling food and other courses. With this loan, the Señora will be able to work better as she will be able to count on working capital.

properties.title: Bethania Group : Tanzania
properties.description: $3,225 of $3,275 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Asia, who is in her late 30s, is single with one child who attends school. For the past seven years, she has run a beauty salon. Asia works from eight in the morning until eight at night every day and is able to make a good monthly profit. She is a member of a loan group, called “Bethania,” which has 15 members who will hold each other accountable for repaying their loans. Asia is requesting her fourth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used her previous loans to enlarge her salon building and provide for her household expenses. She has successfully repaid all of her previous loans. Asia will use this loan to buy modern salon equipment to attract new customers. Her dream is to one day open another salon in a different location.

properties.title: Nelia Absalon : Philippines
properties.description: $150 of $300 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 3, 2011 Nelia is 42 years old and married with three children. She earns a living by farming vegetables and rice in the Philippines. Nelia is borrowing 12,000 Philippine pesos through NWTF to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies. Nelia has been farming vegetables and rice for 10 years and also earns additional income from pig fattening. She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream – to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

properties.title: Peter Munyithya Uthuu : Kenya
properties.description: $0 of $800 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Peter is 35 years old, married and has five children. To earn a living, Peter sells kerosene and he has employed one person. He works hard in his business to provide education for his children. Through Faulu Kenya, he has expanded his business. Peter is determined to succeed in his business. He dreams of opening several outlets of his business in five years. Peter has requested for 70, 000 Kenyan shillings to buy kerosene.

properties.title: Vincent : Rwanda
properties.description: $425 of $850 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 1, 2011 Vincent is 42 years old and is married with three children between the ages 11 and 21 years old. Vincent sells cooking oil, body lotion, soap and sugar. He has four years of experience and employs one person to help him. Vincent has requested a loan from Kiva in order to purchase more salt, soap, sugar, cooking oil and body lotion. With these profits, Vincent will pay school fees for his children and save for his family.

properties.title: Nooruzkan Bekbolueva's Group : Kyrgyzstan
properties.description: $1,300 of $2,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 24, 2011 Nooruzkan, 56, is the leader of this group. While residing in a small town of Toktogul, she is married and has two grown children. For 10 years, she’s been busy selling foodstuffs and liquor, which she started with an initial capital of 30,000 soms. Since then, she has increased the commodity turnover and made significant contributions to the family budget. Her husband is a farmer and is happy with this business, too. The entrepreneur has been earning 8,000 soms monthly. Nooruzkan’s purpose for the loan is to purchase more foodstuffs and a variety of drinks in order to increase the range of products that she sells. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

properties.title: Razzak Saiid Ajel : Iraq
properties.description: $1,725 of $2,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 20, 2011 This borrower is from Iraq. He is 43 years old, married and has five children. In 2009, Razzak opened a food market selling food, beverages and sweets. He has more than three years experience in this field, a good reputation and he is well known in his area. He is requesting a $2,000 loan to buy a refrigerator and to increase his market’s inventory. He is optimistic about his business development and hopes that the coming years will continue to bring him positive growth.

properties.title: Kotognogontala 5 Group : Mali
properties.description: $1,300 of $1,550 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 1, 2011 Group Kotognogontala 5's ten members are married women who are on average 37 years old with four children. Most of them live in polygamous families in Fachoribougou, one of the villages of Kaboila Township in Sikasso prefecture (Mali's third administrative region). They collaborate with microfinance organization Soro Yiriwaso to carry out their agricultural activities during the rainy season. They are on their eighth loan with the organization, previous loans having been repaid successfully. The species they cultivate are tomatoes and jakatou for Abi, who is standing up on the right. With her loan, she intends on paying plowing costs and buy fertilizers and seeds to cultivate 2.5 acres. After the harvest, production is sold at the village level and at the Sikasso market to a clientele composed of men and women. She is counting on an average profit of 65,500 FCFA per agricultural cycle. This benefit will allow her to repay her loan and to also help her husband with daily expenses. She wishes to maintain this collaboration with Soro Yiriwaso in order to operate an even larger cultivation space, the better to increase her profits.

properties.title: Lesbia De Jesus : Nicaragua
properties.description: $500 of $950 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 3, 2011 Lesbia is from Chacaraseca, a community located in León. She is 62 years old and has a son. She’s a farmer and raises livestock. She learned this occupation while still a little girl because her parents were farmers. They passed down land to her to cultivate and that’s what she did. She worked hard to have a successful harvest. With income earned she bought animals like cows, chickens and pigs to raise. Despite only completing fourth grade she has known how to get ahead. She works day by day to raise her crops and have a farm today. She asked for the loan to buy oxen to work the land. This loan will help her buy cattle she needs to meet the needs of her farm and to grow vegetables. Her next goal is to grow pumpkins, chayote and peppers to open up a new market for crops she didn’t previously grow and to continue producing to get ahead.

properties.title: Sumera's Group : Pakistan
properties.description: $875 of $900 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 28, 2011 Sumera has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s rent-a-bike business. He has two bikes which he rents out to people and charges on an hourly basis. He has been in this business for the past 7 years and it is earning well for him. With the loan, he will buy another motorbike to start using it in his business to generate more income. He gives full attention to his business and also takes care of his motorbikes because he knows that if his assets work well than he can continue his work and can easily make more money. Sumera hopes that the loan investment will bring positive financial changes to her husband’s business and improve the living standard of her family as a result. Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Sumera.

properties.title: Benson Ochieng Ong'anga : Kenya
properties.description: $75 of $250 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Benson is 26 years old, married and has two school-going children. He runs a retail shop so as to earn a living. He has been in the business for 3 years. Since he joined Faulu Kenya, Benson has learned how to manage his business and save his money. In five years, he hopes to expand his business into wholesale. He has requested 20,000 KES to buy maize flour, rice and sugar.

properties.title: Aura Maria Barrios Sanchez : Colombia
properties.description: $50 of $575 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Aura will purchase, with her new Kiva loan, basic materials in large volume so she may fulfill some orders she received for children's clothing, which will help her much more with her earnings. With her previous loan she purchased materials, made decorative products, and slightly increased her profits. She sends the following message to her financers: "Thanks so very much for everything you are doing for the micro-business owners, it is excellent help." If you would like to know Aura's story, go to the following link: http://kiva.org/lend/219623

properties.title: Martha Cepeda Conya : Ecuador
properties.description: $100 of $600 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Martha, 37, lives in Primavera de Duran (urban outskirts that were originally irregular with several hills, streams and lagoons that are still present as evidence of deteriorating ecology). She’s a widow with two children who are at university. She is a fruit vendor. She chose this activity because she was left a widow with two daughters to support; she decided to sell fruit. She works alone from 7am until 7pm. With help from the loan she wants to pay tuition and buy school supplies for her children and at the same time buy fruit for the business. What she most wishes for is to have a locale that she can sell her products in.

properties.title: Venant : Rwanda
properties.description: $225 of $850 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 1, 2011 Venant is 42 years old and is married with seven children, who are between 2 and 15 years old. He sells boutique items (sugar, salt, rice, maize, etc.) He has 12 years of experience and he employs one person to help him. He works from 6 am until 10 pm every day. Venant has requested his first loan from Kiva partner Vision Finance Company in order to purchase more cooking oil, beans, sorghum, sugar, salt, rice, maize and so on. With these profits, Venant will reinvest in his business and pay his children's school fees.

properties.title: Rosita Calib-Og : Philippines
properties.description: $25 of $250 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Rosita is married with 7 children. She is 66 years old and lives in Plaridel. To earn a living, Rosita sells a variety of products from her general store. She has had this business for 3 years. Each month, she earns 10,000 PHP doing this type of work. She has requested a loan for 10,000 PHP to purchase more stock for her general store. Rosita has been a member of PMPC for 10 years.

properties.title: Benkadi 5 Group : Mali
properties.description: $1,425 of $2,150 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 1, 2011 The 10 members of this BENKADI 5 group are married women with an average age of 41 and three children on average, who mostly live in polygamous families in ZERLABA, one of the villages of the township of PIMPERNA in the prefecture of SIKASSO, third administrative region of Mali. They collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso so that they can succeed in their agricultural activities during the rainy season. They are on their seventh loan with the institution, and their preceding loans were correctly reimbursed. The crops they cultivate are tomatoes and "jakatou" (a local vegetable), as for example in the case of DJENEBA, the first standing on the left in the photo. With her loan, she intends to pay for plowing expenses, to buy farm inputs, and seeds to farm one hectare of land. Her produce is sold in the village and in the market of SIKASSO after the harvest, to a clientele composed of men and women. She expects to make an average profit of 145,500 F CFA per season. This profit will allow her to repay her loan and to help her husband with day-to-day expenses. She hopes to continue this collaboration with Soro Yiriwaso so as to better manage her land and thus earn more from farming it.

properties.title: Solidaridad Group : Peru
properties.description: $2,100 of $3,200 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 24, 2011 If there is something that Rosa is noted for, it is the good flavor of her food. She recalls that on one occasion somebody asked her for 200 tamales for a wedding party. She received a lot of compliments as her tamales were delicious and so she started a business preparing food for all occasions. She also sells food from her own home. This income allows her to help her daughter and her school-age grandchildren. What Rosa would like more than anything is to finish building her home so that she can set up a grocery store in it. She will use her loan money to make progress in her project. Rosa is in charge of the "Solidaridad" group. This is a new responsibility for her and, as the group's president, she would like to do her best as she has belonged to the group for six years. * Rosa is wearing a chequered shawl. There is also a young person in the photo who is not a member of the group.

properties.title: Mhamad : Lebanon
properties.description: $1,325 of $2,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 22, 2011 Mhamad is a 31-year-old married man, living with his wife and one child in Qana. Mhamad works at selling and fixing air conditioners. He's almost the only one in the region doing this. As we know, the summer season is his business's high season, and he has to be prepared for it. That's why he requested a loan from Al Majmoua-Kiva partner, in order to buy air conditioners requested by clients. He doesn't have enough cash on hand to get them. Mhamad opened his own shop in 2007, but he has 10 years of experience in this field which gives him a positive point and his customers trust him. He hopes to expand his business further and to have employees to help in doing quarterly maintenance for customers.

properties.title: Rotha Heng : Cambodia
properties.description: $875 of $950 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Rotha, 30, is a housewife. Her husband is a cattle seller; his income is $15 per day. They have two children who are seven and three years old. Every month, she has to spend $24 on food, $6 on school fees, and $14 on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of $950 to buy some farmland. When she is able to buy this land she will plant vegetables and more to get crops to sell. In the future, she hopes to have some money to buy groceries to sell at her house, and to be able to save enough money to repair her house. For her children, she plans to send them to school until they finish university.

properties.title: Dinara Bekturova's Group : Kyrgyzstan
properties.description: $550 of $775 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 5, 2011 Dinara, 45, is the leader of this group. She and her husband, who is a member of a local farm community, have three young kids. She combined her single mindedness with her enormous creative abilities to guarantee her success. She started farming in 1994 during the peiod of privatization. After twelve years of labor on a field she constructed a house and expanded her herd of livestock. Today she has been widely recognized with her high quality agricultural products and is in high demand. The loan is requested with the purpose of buying fertilizers and medicine for caring for the potatoes that she planted this spring. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

properties.title: Jairo Enrique Julio Santana : Colombia
properties.description: $975 of $1,025 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Jairo visited us and told us that he is very happy because his daughter Jaisa is about to start her third semester at university and this is thanks to Kiva lenders who have supported him with this his third Kiva loan. They will almost certainly help him until his daughter becomes a successful professional. Jairo says that his daughter is an excellent student and deserves all the effort that her family is making to ensure she has successful future. He says that the Kiva loan is a reward for people who have been working with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo for some time and that this is very good. If you would like to know more about Jairo and his story, click on the following links: http://kiva.org/lend/214472 http://kiva.org/lend/262004

properties.title: Amina Chandama : Kenya
properties.description: $125 of $300 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 26, 2011 Amina is a married woman with nine children, all of whom have graduated from school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. For the past ten years, she has operated a retail shop business selling to her neighbors, passersby, and school-going children. Her other source of income is from selling farm products. Seasonality is a major challenge for her. Increases in product prices decrease the number of customers she has. Amina decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. With a loan of 25,000 Kenyan shillings (KES), she plans to purchase wheat flour, sugar, maize flour, cooking fat oil, and bathing soaps. She dreams of expanding her retail shop in the future.

properties.title: Ligaya Bautista : Philippines
properties.description: $0 of $1,175 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 This is Ma. Ligaya, 41, a resident of Silang, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Rosendo, a contractor, and is the mother of four children. She, together with her husband and children, manage their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses and her children’s studies. A dream for most poor Filipino parents, like Ligaya, as she herself has been an undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children. Ma. Ligaya operates a fruit stand. She buys seasonal fruits that are native to the Philippines like pineapples, which are grown mostly in the south region of Luzon. She also sells bananas, papayas and other Filipino fruit staples. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 600 every day. To help her continued business operations, she is requesting a Php 50,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of fruit to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. Ma. Ligaya dreams to be able to give her all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and to also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. * All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

properties.title: Riham : Palestine
properties.description: $1,600 of $2,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 23, 2011 Riham is a young woman and a mother of one son and one daughter. Her husband Sameh, who is photographed in the bookshop as she is a conservative woman, has a bookshop and wanted to add an accessories section besides the books and stationery he sells, as in the picture. Riham took out a loan from FATEN to cover the price of the accessories her husband bought which will improve their financial situation as, due to the financial hardship in Palestine, book-selling income does not cover household expenses.

properties.title: Emmanuel : Uganda
properties.description: $150 of $425 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 27, 2011 Emmanuel is a 24-year old man living in Kasese, Uganda. He has been in the retail shop business for three years. Before that, Emmanuel was a cotton farmer from which he got the capital to start the retail shop. His hardships are thieves and high trading license rates. His vision is to have a big shop ,which sells a variety of products and buy land to construct a family house. Emmanuel needs the loan facility to start the product diversification at his shop by buying clothes to sell.

properties.title: Luis Alcides : El Salvador
properties.description: $900 of $1,025 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 27, 2011 Luis, who has a metal-working workshop, lives with his wife and two sons who are 28 and 22 years old. The two children are still dependent on him, but the eldest helps in the workshop. His work schedule is from 8:00 am to 4:00 pm. This business grew from his own initiative, and its disadvantage is that he has times where he doesn't work because it all depends on customer demand. Currently, he needs to invest in materials for the manufacturing of doors and for the repair of some tools. To manufacture the doors, he needs metal sheets and iron. The tools used are the compressor, welder and some keys. This loan will allow for faster delivery of orders. For Luis, his intent is to keep all the necessary materials and tools in the shop in good condition, because these are the means to carry out his work, which in turn gives him income for his family.

properties.title: Shirley Rojas Rojas : Costa Rica
properties.description: $125 of $1,200 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 5, 2011 Shirley is a 44-year-old woman living with her three minor children and her husband. Because of economic reasons she only went to elementary school. She is a very hard working, enterprising, tenacious person. This is the second loan she’s had with the Fundación. She had excellent payment behavior with the first one. She found out about the program through a television show called “Buen Día.” Shirley will use this loan to stock her store because very good times are approaching and she needs capital. She’s had her store for seven years; she started out with the amount of 300,000 colones and to date her business has improved very much. One obstacle she had to overcome was not having working capital that she needed to stay in business. She rises early every day to get her daughter ready and make breakfast for her husband and children. They then go off to school and she finished up her domestic chores and tends to the store during the course of the day. This loan will allow her to have good working capital to stock her store during the seasons when demand for merchandise is higher.

properties.title: Anonymous : Sierra Leone
properties.description: $700 of $925 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 28, 2011 This borrower is 31 years old. She is married, and has 3 children ages 6, 8 and 12 years old. In 1992, she established her provisions shop. She began her business because she inherited it from her parents. So when she got married, she started doing it for herself from the little money given to her by her husband. She now enjoys doing business because she almost solves all of her problems and is able to assist her husband in taking care of the home. Working 6 days a week and 10 hours a day, she earns about 1,000,000 SLL every month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of 4,000,000 SLL. She requires a loan in order to buy 10 cartons @ 72,000 SLL, mayonaise - 10 cartons @ 190,000 SLL, sugar (cube) - 10 cartons @ 100,000 SLL and soft drinks - 10 crates @ 35,000 SLL. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately 250,000 SLL. She is convinced that in acquiring this loan, her shop will expand more than before, and she even hopes to establish another outlet so that she can assign one of her brothers to be selling there. With a second outlet she could realize more profits and therefore help her husband greatly in taking care of the home. In the future, she hopes to acquire a piece of land and educate her children as well. Some of the profit has been put back into the business and some used to solve domestic problems. She has a plan to expand and continue accessing loans from Kiva partner Association for Rural Development. She is a very hardworking and dedicated woman with a good vision. She thanks you for your support.

properties.title: El Arbolito Group : Mexico
properties.description: $425 of $875 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Guadalupe lives in La Ribera, General Sandino. She’s married to Valdemar with whom she has three children: José Eliazin, 22, Verónica del Carmen, 20, and the youngest, Luis Alberto, 16. She buys ranch raised chickens for subsequent sale butchered in the same location. She’s been in business two years and five months and she comments that she does well since she’s earning income and helping her husband with household income. Wanting to better move her family ahead is what motivated her into this activity. She decided to go into it and it’s producing good results and improving her income. What she wants most is that her children get ahead and with the loan continue to work to obtain better income. The members of the group are: María Aida who will use the loan to buy merchandise to stock her grocery store and Verónica del Carmen who will use the loan to buy crates of chickens to butcher and sell.

properties.title: Clementine : Rwanda
properties.description: $525 of $850 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 4, 2011 Clementine is 40 years old and married with six children between 7 and 23 years old. She owns a small business selling various styles of clothing for weddings and other clothing for sale. She employs one person from her community as a helper and her hours of business are from 8am until 7pm every day except on Saturday. This is her fourth successful year of business. Clementine has requested her first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business by purchasing more clothes for weddings and other clothes to sell. This loan will allow her to attract more customers, which will help her to earn more profit. With this profit, Clementine will reinvest in her business and save for her future.

properties.title: Jameelan's Group : Pakistan
properties.description: $1,600 of $1,875 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 24, 2011 Jameelan is married and has no children. To pass her time and to help her husband financially, she operates a sewing business. She learned this skill from her mother in her teenage years and now she is good at it. She receives orders from her community clients and earns well after completing the orders on time. She also knows how to do embroidery but doesn’t do it on a regular basis. Her husband has a business doing floor polishing. He has a polishing machine and he uses it to polish floors. He is very good at his work and provides services to his customers for a reasonable fee. Jameelan has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to buy a new sewing machine which will help her finish orders on time. Her current machine has become old and takes much time to sew a single dress. She has been operating her business for the past six years and is very hopeful that the investment will help her in making her business more profitable. She is a new loan applicant of Asasah.

properties.title: Iem : Cambodia
properties.description: $825 of $1,200 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 1, 2011 Iem is 41 years old and a resident of Siem Reap Province. To earn a daily income, he provides photo services for his neighbors and other villagers who need him to take a picture for their party or other ceremony. He has a life partner in his wife, who sells many products, such as merchandise, plastic products, fruits, cooking ingredients and soft drinks at home (Iem is pictured inside his house). They are blessed with four single children. Iem will be using his loan to buy a new motorbike for riding to clients’ houses in order to provide his photo service.

properties.title: Concepta Kanza Katunguu : Kenya
properties.description: $200 of $225 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 30, 2011 Concepta has been operating a bar for the last 8 years. She supplements what she gets from this business by engaging in farming. She is a honest, hardworking, and independent 42-year-old business lady. She is a single mother of two children; Kennedy and Denis Ngunu. Her dream is to educate her children and to support the needy and give them hope. She is grateful to Faulu Kenya for inculcating in her the art of saving. She wants 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more crates of sodas.

properties.title: Nanuli Mghebrishvili : Georgia
properties.description: $975 of $1,225 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 5, 2011 Nanuli comes from the village of Ruisi, Kareli District. She is 56 years old and lives with her 34 year-old son. Her son works as a watchman in the local school. Nanuli and her son are involved in farming. They own a 3-hectare plot of land where cabbage, tomatoes, beets, onions, and garlic are grown. Nanuli sells the harvested vegetables locally to vegetable retailers. Also, the family has a milk cow. Nanuli produces cheese and sells it locally. She requested a loan for purchasing tomato seedlings, as well as fertilizers. Also, part of the loan will be used as payment for workers who will help the family with planting the seedlings, as well as fertilizing the land. Nanuli plans to use part of the income for her son’s wedding arrangements this fall. Another part of the income will be reinvested in the business.

properties.title: Melba Mercedes Rueda : Nicaragua
properties.description: $100 of $825 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Melba Mercedes is a married mother of two children, ages 11 and 20. For the last 16 years, she has run a small eatery. The loan proceeds will help her continue to operate her business, more specifically, will help her purchase basic grains she uses in food preparation. Melba Mercedes would like to grow her business and increase the income to be able to support her family better.

properties.title: Laure Abajo Group : Honduras
properties.description: $600 of $1,125 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 5, 2011 Saturnina, Maria Suyapa, and Claudia Carolina, who reside in the San Lorenzo, Honduras, formed the Laure Abajo solidarity group in June, 2011. They will collectively serve as guarantors of one another's loans. Maria Suyapa sells snacks and refreshments and is requesting a loan of LPS 8,000 with which to purchase a refrigerator. The refrigerator will enable her to sell frozen items, such as chocolate-covered bananas, which are very popular in her area. Claudia Carolina sells basic foodstuffs out of her home and is requesting a loan of LPS 5,000 to purchase merchandise. Saturnina runs a small convenience shop where she sells basic foodstuffs and household supplies. She is requesting a loan of LPS 8,000 to purchase merchandise for her store.

properties.title: Jeisson Alberto Fernandez Miranda : Colombia
properties.description: $75 of $450 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Jeisson, 18, lives in the Nuevo Milenio neighborhood in the town of Soledad. He owns a business called "Mr. Ciber" which he set up because of his entrepreneurial spirit and his firm desire to help his mother cover household expenses. Jeisson is a young man with clear goals and a desire to get ahead in his personal, family and business life. He dreams of one day visiting the United States and seeing modern equipment, and of growing his business and turning it into an elegant Internet café in a shopping center with many customers. For now he is planning to add a television set, computer and stationery items to diversify his business and give it an atmosphere of study and research. His main customers are young people who visit him to do their homework or enjoy a leisurely, healthy pastime supported by Jeisson. This is why he is reaching out to credikiva, his first loan through the Santo Domingo Foundation. The new equipment and related merchandise will attract new customers and satisfy current ones. While working to try and meet his goal, he is taking every effort to expand and increase his profit margin, which is no less than 33%.

properties.title: Yolanda : Peru
properties.description: $50 of $550 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Yolanda was born in Quillabamba, Cusco (Perú). She is 25 and lives in Cusco with her only daughter. Yolanda runs a small cafe in the San Fernando School, in Cusco. She has been in charge of the business since March and has been pleased to see the results of her hard work. Yolanda seeks this loan to stock the cafe with food items such as cakes, gelatin and other snacks. Known to be hardworking, she was invited by other members of the communal lender “Mosoc Killa” to participate as a borrower of Asociación Arariwa.

properties.title: Anonymous : Lebanon
properties.description: $850 of $2,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 10, 2011 This Kiva borrower is a 31-year-old single man living with his parents. He is from Lebanon. In 2007, he decided to start running his own business. So, he opened a small mini-market where he sells dairy and daily products, soft drinks, detergents etc. He has obtained two Kiva loans and we note that he has a very good repayment history. Today, he is requesting a loan of $2000 US from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to increase his store’s inventory. In the future, he is planning to enlarge his shop and add a small corner where he will start a home products trading business.

properties.title: Shalom 5 & 7 Group : Dominican Republic
properties.description: $2,225 of $2,825 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 25, 2011 Teolinda is one of the members of the “Shalom 5 & 7” group, located in the town of Hato Mayor, whose economy depends on farming. It is one of the most rural towns in the Dominican Republic. Teolinda's principal economic activity is the sale of clothing. She is the mother of five children, four or whom live with her and their father. She tells us that her most difficult challenges are having sufficient money to cover her family's needs and to have her own house. Teolinda's favorite activity is serving in her business. Teolinda is very moved by receiving her 10th loan from Esperanza Internacional, after having repaid her previous loan satisfactorily, thereby having taken a step towards her business's growth. She has had her business for around five years. She set it up when she saved enough money to start a business and was immediately able to have her first Esperanza loan, all of which she invested in her business. Teolinda will use this loan to purchase jeans, shoes and women's clothes such as blouses, skirts, underwear and other items. She is planning to use her business profits to reinvest and save. Teolinda's most important dreams are to be able to see her children graduate from university and to be able to live in a comfortable house. She thanks all of you for your support.

properties.title: Fred : Uganda
properties.description: $100 of $375 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 30, 2011 Fred is a 32-year-old single male with one child living in a rented house in Kasese, Uganda. He operates a video hall where people can watch movies. He has been in this business for six years, having started with 800,000 shillings worth of capital. He now has 1,600,000 shillings. His hardship is lack of enough capital. His vision is business expansion, buying land and building a house for his family. Fred needs a loan to enable him to buy chairs and a flat screen for his video hall.

properties.title: Yean Im : Cambodia
properties.description: $700 of $1,200 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Yean, 47, is a tailor, and can make $2 per day. Her husband stays at home. They have three children, one is studying and two are working in the garment factory. Every month, Yean has to spend $20 on food, $10 on school fees, and $14 on other expenses. She would like a loan of $1200 to buy land for her husband to farm. She will keep going on her career and extend it more if it does well. She plans to send her children to study at least through high school.

properties.title: Wahhab Razzak Jabbar : Iraq
properties.description: $2,250 of $2,400 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 21, 2011 This borrower is from Iraq. He is 27 years old, single, and lives with seven family members. Wahhab opened a shop for selling and repairing motorcycles in 2007. He has good experience and a good reputation and he is well known in his area. He is requesting a $2400 loan to pay the annual rent for his shop. He is aiming to gain more profits so he can improve his family’s quality of life.

properties.title: Beatriz : El Salvador
properties.description: $500 of $500 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 6, 2011 Beatriz is 34 years old. She is a single woman who lives with her two daughters in her house. Her daughters are 13 and 10 and are in school. She hopes to have enough energy to give them an education until they graduate from college. Beatriz has worked for a long time in order to bring the daily bread home to her daughters. For several years, she has had a business which consists of a small restaurant where she offers delicious dishes. Her business is located in a very strategic area where there are a lot of workers from nearby businesses. Thanks to the cleanliness, quality, prices and above all Beatriz' friendliness, her business is growing and her customers demand more of her every day. This had led her to the decision of asking for this loan from Integral to be able to buy a variety of ingredients, such as beef, chicken, rice, fruit, vegetables, etc. in order to prepare a variety of delicious dishes and attract more customers. In this way, she can make her dream of improving her family's living conditions come true.

properties.title: Jose Luis : United States
properties.description: $1,450 of $1,650 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Jose Luis is the sole owner and employee of a vibrant new fish market in his community. He sells fresh and frozen fish, cooked seafood and condiments of packaged food items and seasonings. Neighbors flock to his store daily to purchase whole fish, shrimp, and clams and mussels. Although his fish market is only a year old, he has been in the United States for over 8 years and his experience has inspired him to maintain a thriving business. With this loan from ACCION USA, Jose Luis will be purchasing new ingredients and seasonings to expand his product offering. He looks forward to further pleasing his current customers and obtaining a greater client base in the upcoming months.

properties.title: Ayidekon-Fifa Group : Benin
properties.description: $550 of $675 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 6, 2011 Group Ayidekon-Fifa is composed of three residents of the same district in Benin. The group's representative, named Augustine Louise, is the woman raising her hand on the picture. This is the third time that this group is requesting ALIDé's financial support in order to increase their level of activity. Augustine Louise is married to a welder named Thomas and has seven children, who go to school. Out of the seven children, five depend on her financially. Augustine Louise and her husband take care of the family's various expenses together. Augustine Louise did not have much schooling, but she learned sewing. She has been in this business for about five years. In addition to this activity, Augustine Louise sells haberdashery items in her workshop. On the side, she also sells fabrics, shoes, bags and baby linen in her workshop. Augustine Louise gets her supplies in Benin and in Togo. Demand from her customers is growing, and given her limited resources, Augustine Louise is having trouble meeting their requirements. Considering this and their limited resources, Augustine Louise and the other members of group Ayidekon-Fifa are requesting a collective loan from ALIDé.

properties.title: Amor Y Esperanza 3, 4 & 5 Group : Dominican Republic
properties.description: $3,425 of $4,375 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 23, 2011 Gislaine is the coordinator of her group Amor y Esperanza 3, 4, 5 (love and hope). She makes her home here in a simple structure with her husband and their two children. She says that her biggest challenge is to give her kids all they need and to educate them. After this 5th loan, she has been able to provide for these changes for her children. She is also planning to develop herself by learning more about her clients and what the community need. Gislaine is excited to be taking her fifth loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She has had her business for almost 5 years. She started by selling different products from a bag with some savings she had. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business by buying big packages of used clothing, also she is starting the sales of new clothing. She had expand her business into more products and clients. She will use the profits to save and reinvest in her business. Her group is located in the urban slums surrounding Santo Domingo. and this group of 15 people is joined by Haitians citizen, who emigrated to the Dominican Republic for a better life.

properties.title: Victor : Rwanda
properties.description: $275 of $700 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 3, 2011 Victor is 34 years old. He is married and has three children between 2 and 9 years old. He sells food such as cakes, biscuits, bread, etc. in his shop. His business is well organized. He works from 7am to 7pm every day except Sunday. He has two years of experience in this business and currently employs one person to help him. Victor has requested a loan from Kiva lenders in order to buy more food such as cakes, biscuits, bread, etc. to sell. With any profit, Victor will reinvest in his business and to pay school fees for his children.

properties.title: Parsimei Kisaka : Kenya
properties.description: $175 of $900 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 30, 2011 Parsimei, aged 43 years, is married and has three children. He has been farming for the past four years. He is a humble client. He knows KADET through other clients registered in his area of dwelling. This will be his third loan with KADET, and he intends to spend it by preparing the land for farming and to purchase maize seeds. He anticipates using the profit generated to restock his farm with maize seeds and fertilizers. He dreams of becoming a big farmer. He can do more if provided with resources.

properties.title: Gladys : Mexico
properties.description: $75 of $600 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Gladys is twenty-six years old. She is single and lives in the Trinidad neighborhood of Copaínala, in Chiapas State in Mexico. She works with her ​​brother in a photocopying store, and she is applying for the loan to invest in purchases from beauty brand catalogs including Avon, Jafra and Arabela. She has been doing this for nine months and says things are going well as she has had good results. The reason she started this activity was for herself, as she wishes to have her own income to support her daily living expenses. She counts on the support of her brother, on top of which she provides support for her mother. What she wants most is to earn her own income from this small activity, so she can move forward in life with her family.

properties.title: Jehova Jaire Group : Zimbabwe
properties.description: $2,025 of $2,300 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 1, 2011 Gladys (the lady with white stockings, fourth from the left) is 45 years of age and from the city Mutare, the capital of Manicaland province in Zimbabwe. She is married with four children aged 22, 23, 24 and 28. Currently only one child is attending school. Her husband is self-employed. Gladys runs a clothing business selling clothes. The business has been in operation for eight years. She says the main challenge faced is failure to get payments on time. Gladys has requested a loan of $400 to boost her business stock by buying more clothes such as t-shirts, trousers and blankets, which is in high demand given that winter has arrived. She says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will allow her to have more disposable income for the family. In the future, Gladys plans to have her own shop.

properties.title: Gaudiosa Gujilde : Philippines
properties.description: $325 of $525 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 2, 2011 Gaudiosa is 49 years old and married with 3 children. She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Gaudiosa is borrowing PHP 22,000 through NWTF to purchase feed and vitamins. Gaudiosa has been raising pigs for 4 years and also earns additional income from dried fish sales. She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough money to afford to send her children to college.

properties.title: Mairam Alieva's Group : Kyrgyzstan
properties.description: $125 of $900 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Mairam is the treasurer of this group. She is 37 and married to a tractor driver whose monthly salary is about 5,000 soms. Together with her husband, she is bringing up two sons and two daughters. The sons and the older daughter are at school, but the second daughter is not yet as she is preschool age (under seven). Five years ago, with an initial investment of 8,000 soms, Mairam opened a trade place and started to sell foodstuffs. At the moment she earns about 8,000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, Mairam wants to purchase more foodstuffs and detergents for trade. In the future she plans to expand her business and, with the profits gained, Mairam will start building a house. ====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

properties.title: Vukuzenzele Group : South Africa
properties.description: $325 of $625 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Tholakele is 50 years-old and single with 6 children between the ages of 16 and 36. She takes care of one relative. She runs an agricultural business in Kwa Zulu Natal in Mandini in South Africa. In the photo she is rasing her hand. She has been in this business for two years. She sells live chickens from her home and wants to start selling red meat. She also receives income from the goverments child support grant. She requested this loan throgh WDB and Kiva to buy livestock chickens and red meat. Tholakele says that the extra income form this loan will help her generate more profit and take care of her and her family's needs. She faces a challenge of customers who buy on credit and fail to pay. In the future, she would like to own a supermarket. She commented that she is exited about Kiva and that they will show her business on the internet.

properties.title: Edith : Peru
properties.description: $325 of $375 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Edith is 38 years old and married to 40 year-old Julián. The couple have four children and live in Puerto Mayo community, in Pichari district. Edith remembers that she started out farming when she was still a girl, on her parents' farm. She spent most of her time sowing and harvesting products such as cacao and coffee. Edith saw an opportunity. She saw that cacao was in great demand and so started setting out her own plantations. She then started farming independently from her parents after having thanked them profusely for the training that they had given her. Edith currently produces cacao in large volumes which provides her with a good profitability. For this reason, she tries to protect her main source of income from any pests that appear and she normally receives help from her partner. However, during harvest season, she needs help from laborers who make it easier for her to pick her produce efficiently and effectively. This is Edith's second loan from MFP. She pledges to be punctual in making her loan repayments so that she can ensure she is able to take out further loans in the future. She will invest her 1,000 Peruvian soles in having her cacao plants pruned. Edith is happy to be a member of her community bank because all the members are very supportive of each other.

properties.title: Manala Stella : South Sudan
properties.description: $225 of $275 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 At present, she is working in another saloon. she want to rent a shop and make a saloon.

properties.title: Erlinda Castillo : Philippines
properties.description: $275 of $425 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 2, 2011 Erlinda works hard to support her family. She is married and has a fishing/fish-vending business in the Philippines. Erlinda requested a PHP 18,000 loan through NWTF to purchase fishing nets, gasoline and other fishing gear. Erlinda has been in this business for seven years now. In the future, she would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

properties.title: Peter Mbindyo : Kenya
properties.description: $200 of $225 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 5, 2011 Peter is 45 year old, married to Hellen and is blessed with four children. Peter owns a fruit shop whereby he supplies fruit to his neighborhood. He has been in business for the last nine years and earns an income of 18,000 KES a month. Peter is applying for a loan of 20,000 KES, his first from KADET LTD, which he will use to buy fruit and pumpkins to sell. He hopes to educate his children, become a fruit distributor in Githurai and build a house for his family.

properties.title: Enkh-Amgalan Tumurtogtokh : Mongolia
properties.description: $1,775 of $2,025 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 11, 2011 Enkh-Amgalan, 37, is a professional driver. He lives with his wife, mother-in-law and two children, aged 12 and 15, in his mother-in-law’s small house, in Mongolia’s capital, Ulaanbaatar. Both of his children attend public school. His wife works as a separator at a local cashmere factory, while his mother-in-law is a retired and she stays at home. Enkh-Amgalan worked as a driver at a local public transportation company from 2002 to 2008. Since 2008, Enkh-Amgalan has been running a transportation business using his family minivan. He has permission to carry passengers on one of the city’s remote bus lanes which lacks bus services. He is planning to sell his old car and purchase another second car, due to safety regulations for transportation. He is requesting a 2,500,000 MNT to purchase the second car. He said “I wants to improve my business and then to be able to buy my own house”

properties.title: Janet Saho : Ghana
properties.description: $150 of $275 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 3, 2011 Janet is married and has five dependents. Her husband is a farmer. In the photograph Janet has displayed toffees, biscuits, matches, sugar and other items that she sells at Elmina, a fishing community on the Cape Coast. She wants to increase the quantity of goods sold and so a loan will serve as increased capital to buy more of the above mentioned items to sell. She responsibly supports her husband in feeding, clothing and educating her children. Her new profit will be reinvested back into the business.

properties.title: Georgina : Mexico
properties.description: $50 of $450 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Señora Georgina lives in San Juan, near Coapilla. She is a single mother with a daughter named Rosalba Esther, who is eight years old. She has been working in her grocery business for six years and four months, and is requesting the loan to invest in the purchase of goods to keep her store well stocked, as it is through this that she earns income so her young daughter can move forward in life. She was inspired to do this activity so as to have her own income, and in this way she earns her own income. With this she can provide the best for her daughter.
