Therefore, Oyunchimeg is requesting the loan to purchase some car spare parts from China. “I want to grow up my business, and I want to give some properties to my sons when they marry. That is my wish in the near future. And I really appreciate the Kiva team and lenders! Thank you all,” she said.

properties.title: Anastasiya Reznikova : Ukraine
properties.description: $925 of $2,525 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 2, 2011 Anastasiya is married and has a small son. She sells all kinds of souvenirs at an open market in Novaya Kahovka. Anastasiya started this business nine years ago because she needed to support her family. Today her business is doing well. Anastasiya enjoys selling souvenirs very much and would like to develop her business further. Anastasiya is requesting a loan of 20,000 Grivnas to increase the assortment of souvenirs to sell and attract more customers. Anastasiya is hoping to receive additional income and improve her living conditions.

properties.title: Oeum : Cambodia
properties.description: $900 of $1,200 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 3, 2011 Mrs. Oeum has been earning a living by selling different kinds of vegetables, which she and her husband plant on their own farmland or buy from other local farmers in province of Siem Reap. They have given birth to six children; two of their children are employed while the remaining four go to school. Mrs. Oeum’s kids are concerned that they face difficulties in traveling to their workplace. They always travel to work by hiring a taxi or walking because they don't have their own motor vehicle. To solve the trouble, Mrs. Oeum has requested a loan in the amount of $1200 to be used to buy a new motorcycle for her kids to ride to work without hiring a taxi.

properties.title: Nasreen's Group : Pakistan
properties.description: $1,225 of $1,525 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 24, 2011 Nasreen is a seamstress by profession. She operates her sewing business at her home. She sews clothes for her neighboring clients. She is very skillful and receives regular orders every month. Besides her sewing work, she also manages her household responsibilities very efficiently. She is married with three children. All of them are enrolled in a local school and getting their education. Her husband is a rickshaw driver and provides transport services to the passengers. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband who will use the loan to repair his rickshaw. His engine is creating problems and needs repair work. Otherwise, it will be seized. He has been providing transport services to his passengers for over many years and Nasreen is confident that after repairing his rickshaw, he will be able to provide better transport services to his passengers and will make a positive impact on his business.

properties.title: Rosa Mistica Group : Paraguay
properties.description: $3,050 of $3,575 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 5, 2011 The contact for the founding of this committee was Irma, who invited and organized her friends and neighbors to form part of the Entrepreneurial Women's Committee program, since she had heard many good things about this program, and all of them wanted to give it a try together. Irma has been married to Julio for 17 years. She works producing and selling cleaning products. Thanks to this work, she has been able to help her family and her children get ahead. She dreams that one day she will be able to open a general store where she can sell all types of items. She defines herself as a very determined woman; she has always worked and she isn't afraid of doing so. She reports that all of the work she has done has been aimed at ensuring that her children never face the same lack of necessities that she had to endure. She is requesting the loan to buy ingredients that she will use to produce cleaning products, such as essences, colorings, liquid soaps, fragrances and others.

properties.title: Anonymous : Lebanon
properties.description: $1,375 of $2,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 10, 2011 This Kiva borrower is a 47-year-old married man from Lebanon. He lives with his wife and three children. He has made his living as a professional driver, operating a van service for students in his village as well as neighboring towns, for over 25 years. In addition, he offers transportation services for customers upon their request. He cooperates with his wife who works as a teacher in a local school to be able to afford the high cost of living. Today, he is requesting to borrow $2000 US from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to perform much needed maintenance on his van, including changing the tires and repairing the engine. In the future, he is planning to purchase a new van and hire a part timer employee to work on it.

properties.title: Heraclea Caballero : Philippines
properties.description: $400 of $700 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 2, 2011 Heraclea is 40 years old. She is married and has 4 children. She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Heraclea has been raising pigs for 7 years. She also earns additional income from selling dried fish. Heraclea is borrowing PHP 29500 through NWTF to purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs. She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

properties.title: Sugheylis : United States
properties.description: $1,950 of $3,725 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 5, 2011 Sugheylis worked two jobs to save up for her new neighborhood deli. She enjoys being self-sufficient and having the opportunity to help family members back home in Venezuela and Mexico. Sugheylis works full-time as a personal administrative assistant at a wholesale fish distributor and works at her deli on the weekends while her fiancé manages it during the week. Although she is proud of the growing family business that she has created, Sugheylis realizes that she needs better restaurant/food equipment to increase sales and efficiency. With this loan from ACCION USA, Sugheylis will be purchasing a new grill, freezer, and air conditioner for her deli. She looks forward to starting her own family in the future and hopes that the business that she created will be something of which the entire family can be proud.

properties.title: Ruqaya Soboh : Palestine
properties.description: $1,825 of $3,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 24, 2011 Ruqaya, her husband and two sons built a new house. They managed to build it after eight years of marriage and saving money. Ruqaya needs $3,000 to finish the kitchen, and she wants to pay for tiles and window installation. Ruqaya took out a loan from FATEN to pay for the tiles and window expenses as they can't move in without having the kitchen ready for use. Ruqaya is a conservative woman from Ramallah, hence her husband Jad is photographed instead.

properties.title: Duhorimbere Ii Group : Burundi
properties.description: $1,025 of $2,300 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 27, 2011 Louise is a 31-year-old retailer who lives in Gatumba neighborhood in the Mairie district of Bujumbura. She has been selling rice for six years. This is a trade she took up right after leaving school. She is a single mother of two children, aged 13 and 11, who are enrolled in school. She has a secondary school Leaving Certificate in education. Her loan of 170,000 Burundi francs will contribute to growing her working capital and thus the quantity of rice she can stock in order to make more profit. She is a member of the community group « DUHORIMBERE II».

properties.title: Adwoa Agyaa : Ghana
properties.description: $550 of $675 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 4, 2011 At a village called Jukwa, Adwoa sells second-hand clothes. She has been in this trade for 5 years and has been through junior high school. She is divorced and has three children. As a single parent, she pays school fees, feeds and clothes her children. She wishes to invest the amount she is going to receive into the clothing business so that she can take care of her children properly. The new profit that will be realized will be reinvested back into her business for further growth.

properties.title: Jessica Del Carmen Largaespada Galo : Guatemala
properties.description: $475 of $925 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 6, 2011 Mrs. Jessica likes to strive to support herself. She has a beauty salon where she works day by day. She shares that the number of her clients has increased and thanks to this, her earnings have grown. She is asking for this loan to buy cosmetics for the beauty salon. She realizes that she lacks the capital to work. Her dream is to have another beauty salon so that in the future she will be better off economically.

properties.title: Mahudjro 18 Group : Benin
properties.description: $275 of $675 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 3, 2011 Mahudjro 18 is a group composed of three people who are members of the same trade association. The representative of the group, Véronique, who is raising her hand on the photo, was born in a city in Benin on June 25, 1987. Véronique is married to Joseph, a merchant. The spouses have two children, of whom one is supported by them. None of the children attends school. Véronique learnt the dressmaking trade and has been in this business for six years. Her activity gives her enough income to provide for herself and contribute to household expenses. Next to her activity, she sells firewood. Véronique needs to equip her workshop with a new sewing machine in order to better meet the demand of her customers. It is the second time that Véronique and her fellow members of Mahudjro 18 Group applied for financial assistance from the microfinance institution Alidé to strengthen their working capital and boost their activity level and better meet the needs of their customers.

properties.title: Haydar Rahi Hammoud : Iraq
properties.description: $650 of $2,700 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 21, 2011 This borrower is from Iraq. He is 28 years old and married. Haydar has owned a mobile phone shop since 2010; he sells phones and mobile accessories. He has a good reputation and he is well known in his area. He is requesting a $2700 loan to make an advertising light box and get a sliding door for his shop. He is aiming to gain more profits so he can improve his family’s quality of life.

properties.title: Anonymous : Sierra Leone
properties.description: $400 of $925 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 28, 2011 The borrower is 35 years old. She is married and has 4 children aged 8, 10, 14, and 18. In 1996, she established her rice business. She started her business because it would help her husband and her family and, also help to build a house on her land. Working 6 days a week and 10 hours a day, she earns about Le 700,000 every month. She would like a loan of Le 4,000,000 to buy rice - 80 bags @ Le160,000. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately Le 250,000. In the future, she plans to supply to retailers and open another shop. She is very determined and hardworking. She thanks you for your support.

properties.title: Blanca Nelly : El Salvador
properties.description: $650 of $1,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 4, 2011 Blanca lives with her husband and her children who are 8, 13, and 17 years old. She and her husband work together in agriculture and raising livestock. Blanca's parents taught her this work and when she married, she married a farmer so they could share the same economic activity. Currently, she is asking for this loan to purchase pesticide and fertilizer to plant corn since she is beginning preparation so that her crop receives all of the materials necessary for production. Her main goal is to have an abundant harvest, since her income and her family's benefits depends on it.

properties.title: Lira Astrahanova's Group : Kyrgyzstan
properties.description: $750 of $1,300 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 6, 2011 Lira is the leader of this group. She is 44 and married to a constructor. Together with her husband, she brings up three children, all of whom study at school. In order to earn money to support the family budget, Lira breeds livestock and then resells them at a higher price. She has been running this business since 1992. In this way she earns 5,000 KGS per month. Lira applied for the loan because she needs additional financial funds for purchasing livestock. In the future, with the profits gained from reselling livestock, she wants to purchase a vehicle for the family. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

properties.title: Nelson : Bolivia
properties.description: $700 of $1,200 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 13, 2011 Nelson has been married to Obdulia for five years. They are a humble family and have two daughters – Janeth (3) and Elizabet (7). Nelson works in home electrical installation but his work isn’t constant and is scarce. His wife works as a live-out housekeeper and they live at Mr. Rodriguez’ mother’s house located in the Plan 3000 area, 15 minutes from the city. The loan requested is because they need to set up a center for doing assignments and making photocopies, as they live near a school and want to improve their income since Nelson does not have a constant job. Thus way, they can improve their quality of life.

properties.title: Damaris Molina : Nicaragua
properties.description: $600 of $675 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 17, 2011 Damaris is 50 years old. Her business is selling clothes and she has been in the business for more than two years. She started through a neighbor who helps her to get her family ahead in life. This is not the first time that Damaris has worked with Fundación Leon 2000. She is requesting a loan to buy pants, shirts, skirts and a variety of clothes. Currently, most of her customers are requesting a variety of products. Damaris dreams of surviving with her business which is her only way of life.

properties.title: Fred Omariba : Kenya
properties.description: $150 of $525 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 3, 2011 Fred is a farmer in Nyamira, South Rift Kenya. He has been farming for the last 2 years. His farm produces tomatoes, maize and cabbages, which are all sold locally. He is married and has one child, aged 3 years. On his farm, he is helped by two farmhands. Fred also operates a motorcycle transport business. Fred has requested a loan of 46,800 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says he will use the income generated to educate his children, buy more land, and open other businesses to support his farming efforts. He is very optimistic that his business will grow. Like other farmers, Fred too complains about limited financial resources and lack of farm inputs such as fertilizers.

properties.title: Virgilio Del Angel Perez : United States
properties.description: $3,325 of $5,275 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 6, 2011 Virgilio’s San Benito, Texas-based stone memorial business, Del Angel Monuments, is a uniquely community-oriented company. Virgilio prides himself in serving seniors in his Hispanic community by offering them reasonably priced, high quality products. His aim, he says, is to help these seniors provide respectable, well-crafted monuments for their loved ones that fit into their small and often fixed-income budgets. Virgilio’s business, which he began 15 years ago, makes stone memorial monuments for cemeteries. The ideas to start his business came to him while working at a funeral home, during which time he started to create monuments for the customers there. When people began to comment on how much they liked his work and asked for more of his products, Virgilio opened the doors to Del Angel Monuments. Currently, he sells his products directly to members of the Hispanic community and has contracts with various cemeteries in his area. The business has grown enough in the past 15 years to support two full-time employees and two others who are on-call. However, even with these employees, the amount of sketching, measuring, and designing necessary to fill his monument orders was causing Virgilio to work ten to twelve hour days, including weekends. As a result, he decided to modernize his business, utilizing cutting-edge computer design equipment to save time and allow his business to take on more orders. Virgilio used his loan to purchase a computer system called Monu-Cad, worth $15,000, which allows him to map out the design of his products on the computer. It dramatically cuts down on the amount of work he has to do; he says what used to take 24 hours can now be done in an hour and a half. His is the only business that offers that type of quick service in his town, and he is now able to produce and sell significantly more products. In the future, Virgilio hopes to continue offering the affordable, reliable products for his community members along with gaining more large contracts with cemeteries. Since his loan freed up a lot of time that would otherwise be spent hand-designing his products, he believes that he can now truly begin growing into larger markets. His 15 years in business has led Virgilio to offer the following advice on frugality and fiscal responsibility to aspiring business-owners: “You can’t live a luxurious life because your business will claim it; you have to be cautious with your expenditures.” With this knowledge and his newly modernized workplace, Virgilio hopes to continue serving the monument needs of his customers and his community.

properties.title: Yasha Harutyunyan : Armenia
properties.description: $1,450 of $3,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 1, 2011 Yasha is engaged in an agricultural business. He keeps livestock and has agro machinery. Agriculture is the family’s main source of income, but it is not enough to cover the Yasha family’s daily costs. With the requested loan he plans to increase livestock, develop agriculture further, and increase income. Yasha is desperate to improve the living conditions of his family. He lives together with his wife and son.

properties.title: Muhammad : Palestine
properties.description: $1,700 of $3,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 21, 2011 Muhammad is a young man from Palestine. He started working in his grocery store one year ago selling basic household needs such as salt, sugar, tomato paste as well as chips, ice cream, etc. Muhammad wants to expand his business and purchase a larger variety of grocery items to attract more clients and have better income. Muhammad, who appears in the picture, received the loan from FATEN for this purpose.

properties.title: El Porvenir Group : Mexico
properties.description: $1,875 of $3,500 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 This group, named "El Porvenir," decided on this name because this is also the name of the community where they live and where all of them are from. This description will focus on Cruz Esbeidy, since she is one of the members of this group. She is 30 years old and is married to Esteban. They have 2 children; one of them is in school in the second grade and the younger one is barely 2 years old. Cruz has had a business selling cellular telephone cards and recharge minutes for 3 years. She says that she chose this activity because she had to look for a way to provide for her children and help her husband with the household expenses. For this reason she decided to start with this small business, which she says gives her good earnings. She will use the loan she received to buy more telephone cards and recharge minutes. Cruz tells us that her goal is to continue to invest in her business to make it grow a lot more, since she wants to have a cellular phone store so that she can have more income. This way she can cover the educational expenses of her children, since she wants them to continue to study so that they can have a good professional career. She knows her fellow group members well, and tells us that they are responsible people who are hardworking and reliable and who have a strong desire to get ahead and succeed. She thanks the Kiva lenders for their trust and for giving her this opportunity, but most of all for believing in her. Thanks to this support she can invest in her business and in this way have a better future. The members of the group "El Porvenir" and their respective businesses are the following: Irma-fruit sales Julia-chilate (a riced-based drink) sales Viridiana-shoe sales Balbina-cheese sales Eudoxia-grocery store Ángela-clothing sales Leticia- perfume sales Ernestina-fish sales Genoveva- clothing sales Zenaida-grocery store Érick-sign sales Brenda- perfume sales Petra-snack sales María de Lourdes -snack sales Cruz Esbeidy- cellular phone recharges María Edith-meat store Adulfa- snack sales

properties.title: Neamah Salman Kazem : Iraq
properties.description: $925 of $2,100 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 23, 2011 This borrower is from Iraq. He is 40 years old, married and has 3 children. Neamah has had a barber shop since 1995. He has more than 15 years experience in his field, has a good reputation, and is well known in his area. He is requesting a $2100 loan to renovate his shop and to tile the floor. He is aiming to gain more profits so he can improve his family’s quality life.

properties.title: Karayba Group : Senegal
properties.description: $950 of $2,575 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 1, 2011 This solidarity group has been created on July 9, 2002. It is composed of 14 women living in the same neighborhood. Their main activity is retail. Mrs. Filidie, on the right and raising her hand in the photo, is the group’s leader. She is 61 years old. She is married and the mother of eight. She also has nine other children entrusted to her care by relatives. Her business is selling vegetables. She has a good experience in this work which she has been doing for years. This loan will allow her to bolster her capital and to develop her business further. The income will allow her to improve the life conditions of her family (healthcare, food, clothing etc…) and to grow her savings.

properties.title: Moustafa : Lebanon
properties.description: $1,750 of $2,325 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 11, 2011 Moustafa is a 34 year old married man and father of two children, living and working in Bint Jbeil. Moustafa has worked in hardware selling since 2005. His business has expanded through the years and his customers are increasing more and more. Moustafa needs to increase his capital, in order to fulfill his customers needs and requests. To do so, Moustafa has asked for a loan from Al Majmoua, a Kiva partner. This is Moustafa's third cycle with Al Majmoua. All his previous loans have had a positive impact on his business, and he has been a good standing borrower. Moustafa hopes to improve his business more and buy a new truck, in addition to providing his family the best living.

properties.title: Lumière De Dieu Group : Benin
properties.description: $625 of $1,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 3, 2011 The group "Lumière de Dieu" (God's Light) is composed of three people who are members of the same trade association. It is the second time that the group applies for financial assistance from the microfinance institution Alidé in order to boost its activity level. The representative of the group, Frédéric, is raising his hand on the photo. Frédéric was born in Benin on June 6, 1970 and is married to Célestine, a merchant. The spouses have six children who all are still supported by them. Five of them are their own children. Some of the children attend school. Frédéric lives together with his wife and the children. The spouses share the various household expenses. Frédéric attended only elementary school. When he left school, he learnt the dressmaking trade. Frédéric has been in the dressmaking business for 15 years and could provide for his needs and those of his children. Next to his activity, he sells nuts of oil palms. Frédéric gets his supply of sewing articles at a market in Benin. Eager to satisfy the needs of their customers and increase their turnover and income, Frédéric and his fellow members of the group "Lumière de Dieu" applied for their second loan. They have repaid their previous loan on schedule.

properties.title: Lesbia Alvarez Zavala : Costa Rica
properties.description: $525 of $800 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Lesbia is 30 years old, is Nicaraguan and lives in the region of Sarapiqui in Costa Rica's Northern Zone with her husband and 10 year old child. This is the third loan she has requested through Fundación Mujer (The Foundation for Women). She wants to invest in merchandise for the busy season in order to increase her inventory prior to the orders of that period. She sells underclothes and household goods from a catalog. She wants to maintain her financial independence and work at home with her ​​husband who works in construction in the same area. She is providing support for her child in his studies; he is currently attending primary school and she pays for computer classes. They live in a humble way, so her work helps pay for a better quality of life for the family. One of her dreams is to be able to buy a computer so she can continue to improve herself. Lesbia is a hard-working woman who is responsible about her home and her commitments. As for her business, she has established a significant number of customers who buy regularly, and who pay for their orders in two monthly payments. She started her business 4 years ago with a hundred dollars given to her by her husband. Following that, in 2007 she took a loan through Fundación Mujer in the amount of 350,000 colones which she paid back without a hitch. She wants to refinance to purchase merchandise from the catalogs from which she sells. She works on credit with her customers who pay her each month in two installments every two weeks. She pays her bills in cash and at this time wants to invest in a major purchase to cover her orders for the season.

properties.title: Said Sodikov : Tajikistan
properties.description: $1,775 of $2,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 22, 2011 Said is married, with 3 children. He sells various construction materials at the central market in Dushanbe. Said has been in this business for 20 years. He tried selling several types of goods, but then stayed with construction materials. There is little competition because most entrepreneurs at the market sell clothing. Said offers good quality products at fair prices and has gained a good reputation among his clients. He would like to widen the assortment of his inventory. Said needs $2000 USD. He finds this loan very helpful for his business development. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

properties.title: Khem Nouk : Cambodia
properties.description: $725 of $1,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Khem, 42 years old, is a motor taxi driver. His wife is working in the garment factory. Their income is $4 per day. They have six children. Five are studying and one is working in the factory with $3 per day for her income. Every month, he has to spend $50 on food, $10 on school fees and $10 on electricity. He would like to request a loan of $1,000 to help his daughter to open a small grocery shop. For the rest of the children who are studying right now, he will try to support them in school at least through high school. He hopes that all of his children will get their own careers in the future.

properties.title: Jeannette : Rwanda
properties.description: $425 of $850 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 4, 2011 Jeannette is 35 years old and is married with two children aged 7 and 11 years of age. She has a store selling foodstuffs and items such as body lotion, cooking oil, rice, beans and cassava flour. Her business is well organized and she employs two people to help her. She has three years of experience and her business is open from 6 a.m. until 11 p.m. every day. Jeannette has requested a loan from Kiva lenders in order to purchase more foodstuffs and items such as body lotion, cooking oil, rice, beans, cassava flour, etc. for sale. With any profits, she will reinvest in her business and pay her children's school fees.

properties.title: Anonymous : Sierra Leone
properties.description: $650 of $700 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 21, 2011 This is a 28-year-old business man. He is single, and has no children but two additional dependents who live with him because they are his employees. In 2007, he established his bar and restaurant business which serves all classes of people and is located on the outskirts of town. He inherited this business from his aunt who is now living in Liberia. For the past years he has been able to manage this business well. He has a good loan repayment history. Working 7 days a week and 14 hours a day, he earns about Le 950,000 every month from this business. He needs a loan of Le 3,000,000 to buy food items and drinks for his bar and restaurant. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately Le 300,000. In the future, he hopes to improve his business and buy a piece of land. He thanks you for your support.

properties.title: Taleh Aliyev : Azerbaijan
properties.description: $625 of $2,550 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 20, 2011 Taleh is single and has no children. This young man is an IDP (Internally Displaced Person). He is a refugee from the Djabrail region who now lives in the Absheron region with his parents. Taleh is 24 years old. For three years, he has sold disks, cassettes, etc. Now he needs 2000 AZN to expand his shop in order to hold more of his wares.

properties.title: Kalmyrza Asanbaev : Kyrgyzstan
properties.description: $2,000 of $2,225 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 24, 2011 Kalmyrza is a 71-year-old villager from Iyri-Suu village. He has worked as a mechanic for all of his life and was really eager to study so he could instill a love of learning in all of his seven children, three of whom became teachers. In 1960, in order to find an additional means of subsistence for his family, he started his activities in a cattle-breeding business. With the initial capital of 15,000 KGS, he managed to develop his business with the monthly profit of 3,000 KGS. Being a very purposeful and positive person, Kalmyrza works hard to support his family, and today he has one cow, twelve sheep and seven horses at his farm. Kalmyrza plans to use this loan of 100,000 KGS to increase the number of cattle. In the future, Kalmyrza is planning to help his daughter purchase a flat and save money for the payment of the higher education of his grandchild. Bai-Tushum and Partners use Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

properties.title: Emanuel Chepkwony : Kenya
properties.description: $125 of $550 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 27, 2011 Emanuel is aged 32 and has been in farming for six years, producing tea and milk and selling to the local market in his hometown Litein, South Rift, Kenya. Emanuel has made a request for 50,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a motorcycle in order to start up a transport business. He says the transport business has picked up in the area and the motorcycle will also help him bring his own produce to the market in a timely manner. He hopes the business will add to his farming income and expand the businesses significantly. Emanuel points to drought and poor markets as the major challenges in farming.

properties.title: Girumwete Group : Burundi
properties.description: $1,425 of $3,575 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 27, 2011 Annonciate is a 29-year-old merchant who lives in downtown Gitega. She is a member of the solidarity group GIRUMWETE. She started selling foodstuffs (rice and beans) five years ago, and she is also a farmer. She is married to Jean-Bosco, a caregiver. The couple have three children, one of whom is in the fourth grade of primary school. Annonciate herself attended school up to the fifth grade. Her loan of 100,000 Burundian francs will help her to increase her working capital and to bolster her purchases of rice and beans for resale in order to earn substantial profits.

properties.title: San Miguel Group : Paraguay
properties.description: $2,800 of $4,800 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 5, 2011 The San Miguel Committee was formed by a group of neighbors and friends from the city of San Lorenzo. They heard about the Program of Women Entrepreneurs and decided to gather together to form their own committee. There are currently 18 members. All of them work hard and responsibly. These female heads of household decided to find a way to provide for the daily needs of their children and their families. Sra. Maria prepares and sells food. She has a small vending post at the market. Maria wakes up early in the morning and heads to work so that she can prepare and sell her dishes. Someday she hopes to expand her small vending post so that she can accommodate more customers. Maria is requesting a loan so that she can buy everything she needs for preparing her dishes such as meat, chicken, vegetables, oil, eggs, and other items. She has faith that this loan will help her generate more income.

properties.title: Patricia Loo : United States
properties.description: $6,500 of $7,850 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 24, 2011 Ten years ago, Patricia decided to start her business, Loop Services & More, after realizing that her six years of experience in public notary could afford her a more lucrative career than working for someone else. She says that obtaining her license to practice public notary was the simple part; the difficult part was building up her reputation and gaining clientele. One of the ways that Patricia has been able to build clientele is by offering several more services than the average public notary, including income tax filing, income tax preparation, mailing services and immigration paperwork. As a native Spanish speaker, Patricia is also able to provide access to all of these services for the Hispanic communities in the Texas-Mexico border city of Brownsville, where her business is located. Because many of her clients are not educated in the complexities of the government documents necessary to stay and work in the U.S., access to translations of these documents is of the utmost importance to them. She partially attributes her loyal clientele to her ability to provide these much needed services. Patricia feels that her business has had two major successes so far. The first was the speed with which Loop Services was able to expand its clientele base. The second was a letter she received from the Internal Revenue Service thanking her for all of the people that she has helped with her business. Of this letter, she says, “(the letter) made me really happy because I enjoy helping my customers in whatever they need, even if it is just translating something for them.” In the future, Patricia hopes to expand her business to offer still more services and employment to her Brownsville community. She hopes to begin offering payment services for bills, money transfers, and money orders. Currently, she employs one other person, but she hopes that the expansion of her business will allow her to offer more employment to those who need it. With this loan, Patricia bought a post box, painted her office, purchased two desks, and installed an office alarm system. She is in the process of dividing her office space into two different offices, reserving one side for public notary and the other for the services she wishes to add. The loan will also pay for the equipment and licenses needed for these new services. Finally, with the remaining money, Patricia will invest in publicity for her business to bring in more clients. Her experiences in business have led Patricia to advise new entrepreneurs never to lose hope. She says, “I always saw my business as a job; you work to provide good customer service, and, if you’re doing well, the clients will come back.” With this simple, yet effective, business philosophy, Patricia hopes to continue expanding her business and serving the community around her.

properties.title: Khaled Mrad Madi : Iraq
properties.description: $975 of $2,400 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 24, 2011 This borrower is from Iraq. He is 33 years old, married and has three children. Khaled has had a food market since 2009; he sells cheese, juices, bread, daily use items, and dairy products. He has a good reputation and he is well known in his area. He is requesting a $2400 loan to buy a generator, a refrigerator and to make a ceiling for his market. He is aiming to earn more profit so he can improve his family’s quality of life

properties.title: Amor Y Amistad 3 & 4 Group : Dominican Republic
properties.description: $1,600 of $3,800 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 27, 2011 Martire is the coordinator of his group Amor y Amistad 3 & 4 (Love and Peace). He makes his home here in a simple structure with his long-term partner and their two children. Martire is excited to be taking his thirteenth loan with Esperanza, after having successfully repaid his previous loan and having developed his business by expanding his client base and by buying more products. He has had his business for around eight years, starting with the first loan he received from Esperanza, after some neighbors invited him to join the group. He plans to use this loan to invest in his business by purchasing pounds of fish and chicken to sell, as well as coconuts in order to sell their water. He will continue using his business profits to provide a better life for his family by building their house and by providing warm food, clothing, and for other needs. His group is located in Samana, a lush rugged peninsula with a burgeoning tourism industry, where most of the group members sell their products in their communities and surrounding areas. Martire thanks you for your support in helping them achieve their dreams of being successful in the future.

properties.title: Vincent : Rwanda
properties.description: $525 of $1,150 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 8, 2011 Vincent is 37 years old and is married with two children who are 11 months and 3 years old. Vincent makes a living by selling cows. He has been in this business for about three years and the hours of his business are from 6am until 5pm every day except Saturday. He currently employs two people to help him. Vincent has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase more cows for resale. With his profit, Vincent hopes that the number of customers will increase as well as his profits. These profits will be used for further reinvestment and to build a secure future for his family.

properties.title: Yeun Sngoun : Cambodia
properties.description: $750 of $1,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 6, 2011 Yeun (in the photo) is 52 years old and his wife, Vannsrey, is 46. They live along National Road two, approximately twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1983 and have three children: two sons and one daughter. One of their children has full-time employment, another one is a teacher and the third one attends school. Yeun is a policeman. His wife raises chickens and ducks at home. He is asking for a loan of $1,000 to assist his wife in buying additional chickens and ducks to raise and to build chicken coop.

properties.title: Carlos Bances Chozo : Peru
properties.description: $525 of $1,100 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 2, 2011 Carlos is 36 years old, and lives with his girlfriend and his two young children in the rural community of Mórrope en Lambayeque. This is an area known for agriculture and livestock. Carlos raises and sells young animals, and he has 15 years of experience in this business with a fixed clientele. At present, he has a sheep that he cares for in a pen located behind his house. Carlos requests a loan for 3000 nuevos soles from Edpyme Alternativa that will be used to buy animal feed and more animals to increase his production. Also, Carlos will use part of the loan to buy groceries to stock his new business, which will sell food products. Carlos is an enterprising man, with a desire to improve his quality of life. He has good personal references and has already worked with the institution. He has a good credit history.

properties.title: Maha Hammad : Jordan
properties.description: $650 of $1,150 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 24, 2011 Maha is a 34-year-old hard-working housewife who has five children to raise with her husband Maher. The two of them decided four years ago to start a small business together and help each other to succeed, so they started selling cleaning products at home which opened a door during these four years to having a cleaning products refill business. Now Maha is applying for this loan so they can buy more bottles and safe equipment to use when refilling and selling, so they can grow their business and expand. Since Maha is a conservative person, she asked that her husband could appear in the picture instead of her.

properties.title: Zakya : Lebanon
properties.description: $600 of $2,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 3, 2011 Zakya, a 43-year old entrepreneur from Lebanon, is married and has four children. The operator of a shoe store since 2007, she has developed a broad customer base that includes friends, neighbors, and professional contacts. Zakya is extremely proud of her work and believes that it is her experience that has helped her succeed. She learned about Al Majmoua through the local loan officer and has proven to be a good standing borrower and a smart businesswoman. Now requesting her second loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua, Zakya is planning to purchase a collection of new shoes and in the future hopes to further expand her business.

properties.title: Ricardo Franklin Albuquerque Ponce : Ecuador
properties.description: $725 of $1,200 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 26, 2011 Franklin is 32 years old. He is a hard-working man who owns a small butcher shop. Before he started his business he used to work in an agricultural company, where he learned about the meat business. He gradually learned until he had enough capital to start his own business. Franklin currently has his own small meat sales business. He works from 7.00am to 11.30 every day. He sells beef, and also chicken by the pound or whole, to his customers at a low price. He has many aspirations for his business and, for this reason, he would like to continue in it. With this loan, he would like to buy meat and chicken so that he can make more income and thereby provide his son with a good future.

properties.title: Lubna's Group : Pakistan
properties.description: $475 of $1,075 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 24, 2011 Lubna is a caring lady, staying at home and carrying out her responsibilities as a housewife very well. Her husband operates a dry cleaner shop. In his shop, he provides cleaning and clothes pressing services to his customers at reasonable rates. He is very good at his services and deals with his customers very well. Lubna is a mother of three sons. All of them are very young and have not started their education yet. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband who will buy an iron, hangers and plastic covers (for packing clothes) with the loan money. This will help him provide better quality services to his customers and increase his profits. Lubna is a new loan user and this is her 1st loan application to Asasah. She is hopeful that the loan investment will enable her husband to improve the financial condition of his business. Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Lubna.

properties.title: Jesse Wekhuyi : Kenya
properties.description: $450 of $1,125 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 27, 2011 Jesse is a poultry farmer from Kitale town in western Kenya. He has been in the farming business for four years now and employs three farmhands. He is 31 years old and single. Jesse has made his third loan request from Juhudi Kilimo of 100,000 Kes in order to purchase additional chickens and chicken feed. The proceeds from this loan will enable him to expand his farming activities. He says that his biggest challenge has been the expenses incurred in raising the chicks from the time they are hatched to the time they are sold and diseases which cause a massive death of chickens. He currently owns two dairy cows and would like to venture into dairy farming as well and be the sole supplier of milk in his division.

properties.title: Santa Ana Group : Nicaragua
properties.description: $625 of $1,025 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 28, 2011 The Santa Ana Group is composed of three hard working and entrepreneurial women. The group's coordinator is Ms. Karla Patricia, who is 35 years old and sells confections, baked goods, rice pudding, pio quinto [Nicaraguan rum cake], etc. Hers is a family business that, with her work and efforts, has progressed. She will invest the loan money to strengthen her business by buying products in larger quantities. The other group members are Marta, 38, who sells confections and baked goods, and Ana, 40, who has worked with baked goods (she makes them and sells them) for eight years.

properties.title: Janylbubu Mukashova's Group : Kyrgyzstan
properties.description: $200 of $1,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 8, 2011 Janylbubu, 64, is a treasurer of this group. She has been a shepherd for the past 20 years. However, the burden of raising, milking and reselling cattle was laid on her own shoulders when she was widowed several years ago. Fortunately, her two grown sons do their best to help her with this hard labor. The initial capital for the business start-up was 8,000 KGS, which was borrowed from a bank by her brother. A monthly income of 4,600 KGS allows Janylbubu to invest some funds back into the business, as well as save some for personal use. At the present time she doesn’t have many head of cattle. She says three head are just enough for yielding milk and getting enough profits. The purpose of the loan is to purchase a dairy cow for selling milk products. The entrepreneur and her group are grateful to lenders for financial assistance. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

properties.title: Garik Ter-Mikayelyan : Armenia
properties.description: $950 of $2,400 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 11, 2011 Garik was born in 1962 in Kapan. He is married and has two children: a son and a daughter, who studies in the agricultural institute. For about 14 years, Garik and his wife have had their own business. They sell household goods, shoes, underclothes, cereals, etc., at Kapan market. Garik spends part of his business profit for his daughter's education, and another part, he uses to keep his family. This is Garik's tenth loan from Nor Horizon, and he is asking for 900,000 Armenian dram to buy cereals and wheat from villagers and household goods from Yerevan to resell them in the Kapan market.

properties.title: Urtnasan Havtgai : Mongolia
properties.description: $775 of $1,450 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 17, 2011 Urtnasan is 47 years old and lives with his wife and three children in a house in Sansar area of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His wife is a salesperson and his younger two sons go to a secondary school. His older daughter, age 22, gave birth and stays home. He manages a transportation service business in Ulaanbaatar city. He started his business in 2005 with his truck. In addition he works as a welder in order to supplement to his earnings. He makes doors, windows, and window protectors for his customers. Now his business has been stabilized which allowed him to fix his truck. He is a hardworking man who attributes his business success to his good managerial skills. He says, "While working as a welder I have gained much profit. Therefore I am planning to build a workshop in order to expand my business." He is requesting a 1,800,000 MNT loan to purchase construction materials to build his workshop.

properties.title: Daniel : Bolivia
properties.description: $275 of $1,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 21, 2011 Daniel works in the Bolivian Armed Forces. He will use the loan to buy his uniform and equipment he needs to continue with his studies. He lives in his parents’ house in La Paz’s Bolonia neighborhood. He’s single and does not have any children. This is his first loan request.

properties.title: Magno Dioulacolon Group : Senegal
properties.description: $1,925 of $3,300 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 1, 2011 This group was created on December 14, 2010. It comprises 29 women who all live in the same village. They all have small businesses. Goundo (standing at the far right) is the group's official. She is 46 years old, a widow, and the mother of two children. She runs a tangana, where breakfasts are sold in the village. She has had this business for three years. Her new loan will enable her to buy sacks of black-eyed peas, packets of spaghetti, and other products for her business to operate properly. The profits will allow her make sure her children are educated, as well as to save money.

properties.title: Qoriwasi Group : Peru
properties.description: $2,725 of $3,700 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Mrs. Miria is a member of the communal bank "QORIWASI", which is located in the district of Huanchac in the province and deparment of Cusco. She is 48 years old and single. She is a teacher by profession and also runs a grocery store with her mother. She is requesting a loan to buy basic needs products such as rice, sugar, pasta, flour and milk to stock her store. The other members are involved in store management, teaching, working as caregivers for children and the elderly, retailing and running grocery stores. This member is grateful for the support and committed to paying back the loan on time.

properties.title: Santo Domingo (Portoviejo) Group : Ecuador
properties.description: $2,550 of $3,975 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 6, 2011 The “Santo Domingo” communal bank meets every two weeks in the outskirts of Junín Canton. This city is known for its kind, hard working people and because it’s here that the province’s and Ecuador’s best aguardiente (alcoholic spirits) is distilled. This is a group of people that decided to join together and form this communal bank which is very useful for them because they can improve their small businesses with the loans. They are in a variety of activities like commerce, services and food sales, among other activities. We met Letty, 33, here. She’s in a common law relationship and has two children who are 14 and 12 years of age and in school. Her husband’s a merchant. She is studying Nursing. She’s in the 6th year at university but she only attends Saturdays and Sundays. In addition to her studies, she’s also in commerce. She sells all types of clothes door to door and takes advantage of the weekends to sell to her classmates and acquaintances. Three days a week she also sells throughout the city especially during the morning when her children are in school. In the afternoons she cares for her children. She tells us that she’s had the business for a year and plans to use this loan to go to Guayaquil to buy more merchandise. She is going to use this loan to buy pants, blouses, t-shirts and children’s clothes. This is her first cycle in the communal bank and she likes the ease with which loans are obtained. Her dreams are seeing her children complete their schooling and become good professionals.

properties.title: Akuvi : Togo
properties.description: $1,025 of $1,100 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 3, 2011 42 years old, Akuvi is married and mother of 2 children. Her husband, meanwhile, is a policeman. On a daily basis Akuvi is a retailer of eggs and packs of mineral water called "Chez Nous Pure Water" and bottled mineral water. To make her contribution, she started her business in 2009 and stocks up at the main market before reselling at Agoe Atsanve in her store opposite the place selling yams. She is asking for a new loan to increase her inventory and better satisfy her customers.

properties.title: Las Margaritas 2 Group : Mexico
properties.description: $4,350 of $4,700 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 This group is called Las Margaritas 2 (The Daisies 2). The members decided upon this name because they are pure women who can identify with the flower. This description is about Magali, who is part of this group. She is 23 years old, married and has a son, 8-year-old Eduardo, who is in his third year of school. Magali has made a living making and selling pizzas for the past four years. She decided to start this business out of necessity because she didn't have sufficient income for her son's education and to give him a better quality of life. She plans to invest the loan in the purchase more ingredients to make her pizzas, such as tomatoes, tomato sauce, flour, ham, meat, cheese, pineapple, sausages and peppers. She wants to continue investing in her business so she can set up a pizzeria, since then she will increase her production and selection and improve and increase her sales and profits. In this way she can keep supporting her son's education and in the future he can end up with a very good career. She chats with all her fellow group memeber, who are responsible women who all know each other and don't have any problems with one another. Magali says she is very grateful to Kiva and FRAC, since thanks to them she is continuing ahead and has been able to start her own business and support her son. The women who make up the Las Margaritas 2 group and their activities are as follows: Magali - selling pizzas; Abelina - selling beans; Isabel - selling perfumes; Floricel - selling shoes; Bertha - selling candy; Eulali - running a taqueria; Herminia - running a fruit stand; Lazara - selling fish; Divina - selling clothing; Paula - selling snacks; Ponciana - running a fruit stand; and Paula - running a corn mill.

properties.title: Mastona Mansurova : Tajikistan
properties.description: $975 of $1,200 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 30, 2011 Mastona is 28 years old and has four children. She sells men's shirts and shoes at the central market. Mastona has been in this business for 17 years. Good location and a positive attitude towards customers have helped Mastona to develop her business. This business is the main source of income for her family. Mastona is asking for a loan of $1200 USD to expand her inventory. She hopes to increase her sales and make additional profit and improve her living conditions. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

properties.title: Lukovani Makuto : Kenya
properties.description: $925 of $1,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 23, 2011 Lukovani has operated in the transport industry in Naivasha town for the past three years. He also plants sugarcane, to sell, on his farm. He is 33 years old, married to Susan, and they have three children. Lukovani was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his third loan. He has repaid all his previous loans well and in good time. He plans to use the loan amount to plant sugar cane on his farm and to sell the cane after its maturity. In the future, Lukovani hopes to buy a taxi which he will operate in Naivasha town. The taxi business is more profitable, compared to motorbikes.

properties.title: Fatemah : Lebanon
properties.description: $1,875 of $2,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 23, 2011 Fatemah is a 56-year-old married woman and the mother of three children. She has worked since 1997 at selling baby diapers and sanitary napkins from her house. She intended to work from her house in order to stay next to her children. Taking good care of them at the same time made for the best management of her business. This is Fatemah's eleventh cycle with Al Majmoua. She is requesting a loan in order to increase her capital through buying big quantities with special prices. In addition, she will help her son in building his own house, through a small payment she will give him. Fatemah is encouraged by most of her customers, neighbors and family, and this what has helped her to stay this long and expand her business. She hopes to open a big shop in the future.

properties.title: Koko Yaa Oduro : Ghana
properties.description: $850 of $1,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 5, 2011 Koko is into multiple businesses; hair dressing, selling cooking utensils, tops and jeans at Abura. Koko went to a vocational school. She is a single parent with a child. She is responsible for the well-being of the home. Her loan will be used to buy more hair products to use on her customers hair. Her new profit would be ploughed back into her businesses for further growth.

properties.title: Suad Hamad : Palestine
properties.description: $2,775 of $3,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 17, 2011 Suad and her husband have a perfume store selling perfumes that are produced from perfume oil. Suad has three sons. Suad and her husband want to expand the store and start selling accessories. They are maintaining a good reputation and they want to seize the opportunity and attract more clients by starting to sell accessories. Suad's husband is photographed in the store, as she is a conservative woman from Jabalia Refugee camp.

properties.title: Yan : Cambodia
properties.description: $825 of $1,200 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 2, 2011 Yan, 31, is a homemaker who stays at home to care for her kid and does her daily routine as well. Her husband provides for the family’s expenses with his income as a policeman and makes a profit of about $6 a day to use for family’s needs. Recently, the family had a problem with their living conditions as their house is getting old and it needs to be repaired but they don’t have sufficient money to do the work. Therefore, Yan has decided to apply for a Kiva loan in an amount of $1,200 to be used to repair her old house.

properties.title: Salamatu : Sierra Leone
properties.description: $1,125 of $1,150 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 21, 2011 Salamatu is 43 years old and married with three children between the ages of 15 and 20. She runs a boutique in Tengbeh Town, just outside of Freetown. Salamatu has been in this business for five years and sells shoes, bags, clothes, and hair products at her store. Her business helps increase her savings and improve the family income. Salamatu says that her main business challenge is inflation. Salamatu is requesting a loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more boutique items. She says that the extra income from her loan will help her educate her children. In the future, Salamatu would like to continue to expand her business.

properties.title: Ndeeba Tukorerehamwe Group, Kihihi : Uganda
properties.description: $2,700 of $2,775 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 22, 2011 George is the leader of Ndeeba Tukorerehamwe Group, Kihihi. He is a very hard worker. He has had a produce selling business dealing mostly in beans and rice sales from Kihihi Town for two years. He generates 100,000/= as weekly profits. George also has a retail shop as his mother's business from which he gets capital for the produce sales. He is 30 years old and married with two children aged 5 and 2 years and his dream is to see his business grow and have a self-reliant family in the future. He needs a loan to be able to buy more rice and beans for an expansion in business.

properties.title: Paz Del Carmen Vallejo Trujillo : Nicaragua
properties.description: $800 of $900 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 20, 2011 Paz del Carmen is from the El Sauce municipality, and she has lived there for many years. She is a tenacious woman who has gotten her three children ahead through her own efforts. She is a widow, and she currently has her own business. The business is a store, which is located in her home. She sells general groceries, clothes, and sandals. Also, on the week-ends she sells food like “nacatamales” (a traditional Central American dish similar to tamale) and soups. Ever since she started her business she has been known for taking good care of her customers and giving them good service. She has worked with Ceprodel for many years. They have given her 13 consecutive loans. Thanks to the loans has been able to keep her business stocked and to build her own house. One of the things that this woman needs is more capital to get more merchandise and to diversify her products. Her objective is to satisfy her customers’ demand. That is why she decided to request her 13th loan with Ceprodel in order to meet her objective.

properties.title: Titomagba Group : Benin
properties.description: $275 of $650 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 3, 2011 The TITOMAGBA group consists of three people whose president (the one with her hand raised in the photo) is named Marguerite. The group members are old friends. In order to increase their working capital, this group is asking for their third loan with ALIDE. Marguerite was born in 1971 in Benin. She is married to a chauffeur named Noel. The couple have three children, all in school, one of which is their dependent. After dropping out of primary school, Marguerite started, ten years ago, to prepare food (rice, corn pasta with sauce, etc.) that she sells in her neighborhood. Marguerite stocks up at one of the markets in Benin. This business generates income that helps her to take care of the various family expenses. This third loan will certainly allow Marguerite and the other members of the TITOMAGBA group enahnce their business and increase their number of customers and their income.

properties.title: Maria De Los Angeles Sanchez Molina : Costa Rica
properties.description: $500 of $1,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 5, 2011 María de los Ángeles, 61, lives with her husband and two children. Due to economic reasons she was unable to complete elementary school and has worked since she was a little girl. This is the first time she’s asked for a loan from the Fundación which she learned about through an organization called INAMU; they were the ones that referred her. She makes rugs out of pieces of cloth, purses, seat covers and some orthopedic neck braces. She intends to use the loan to invest in raw materials to make her products and to have capital to continue investing. María started out with the amount of 20,000 colones to buy her first sewing machine 30 years ago. She rises early every day to do her domestic chores and later she starts sewing until the afternoon and after that she focuses on selling. An obstacle she faces is that her mother is sick and she has to travel to Guanacaste every two weeks to care for her. Her goal is to eventually have a shop with a lot of work. This granted loan will be of great benefit for her because she’ll be able to have more working capital and will be able to buy more, better quality fabric.

properties.title: Rosa Emilia Sanchez : Honduras
properties.description: $375 of $425 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Rosa is lives in the town of Danli in southern Honduras where she earns a living by making women’s clothing as well as offering seamstress services. Rosa has been engaged in this line of work for the last 38 years and has a reliable customer base made up of teachers and students in the area. She is requesting a loan of Lps. 8,000 to purchase materials needed for making and repairing clothing.

properties.title: Cecilia Ladon : Philippines
properties.description: $300 of $325 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Cecilia is 58 years old and a widow with four children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Cecilia has a home products sales business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 10 years. Cecilia requested a PHP 13,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy more stocks of plastic wares to sell. In the future, Cecilia would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

properties.title: Sundas' Group : Pakistan
properties.description: $900 of $2,125 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 24, 2011 Sundas is 24 years old and married with a nine-month old son. She gives him her full attention and takes care of him. She is a housewife who prefers to stay at home and do her household responsibilities. Her husband is an electrician by profession and provides electricity and electrical tool repairing services to his clients. Being an electrician, he needs to deal with electric current all the time but he is very much an expert and has a lot of experience in his profession. Sundas has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the betterment of her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy electricity repairing tools and a drill that will allow him to perform his work better and provide better repair services to his clients. He has been operating this business for the past 20 years and Sundas is very hopeful that an investment will bring better profits to her husband by improving his business.

properties.title: Batdelger Lhagvajav : Mongolia
properties.description: $2,350 of $2,775 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 24, 2011 Batdelger is 38 years old and lives with his wife in a ger, Mongolian yurt, in his older brother's backyard. They live in Songinohairhan district, Ulaanbaatar, capital city of Mongolia. His wife is a sales person who operates her own grocery store. Batdelger manages a goldsmith business at a rented booth at a trading center called Duuhee. He started his business in 2009 and has been able to stabilize his business. Now he is one of the experienced businessmen who managed to build a strong customer base. He is planning to have his own workshop in the near future. He is a polite man who says, "I am planning to save my earning in order to buy a plot of land where I can build a house for my family." He is requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan to purchase a plot of land for his family use.

properties.title: Marat Artemyan : Armenia
properties.description: $2,250 of $2,700 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 27, 2011 Marat is 40 years old, and he lives in the village of Tsav in the Syuniksky region. Marat is married. He has two sons, an eleven-year-old and a twelve-year-old. Marat has been working in agriculture for more than ten years. On his farm he raises cattle, pigs, and bees. He grows potatoes and string beans. His produce (beef, pork, milk, honey, potatoes and string beans) are sold in shops and booths in the cities of Kapan and Kadzharan. Marat's wife helps him on the farm, and thus they support the family. Marat needs to take out a loan for 1,000,000 drams to harvest hay and to acquire several beehives and frames for honey and beeswax.

properties.title: Janylkan Mamyralieva's Group : Kyrgyzstan
properties.description: $850 of $1,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 8, 2011 Janylkan, the 41-year-old leader of this group, resides in the town of Balykchi, which is translated from the Kyrgyz language as “Fisher.” Balykchi is a small fishing town situated by Issyk Kul lake, a location that affords many business opportunities to local residents. A high percentage of the 42,000 residents rely on summer tourism to bring in a large number of visitors both from abroad and from within the republic. With good cooking skills, Janylkan has worked as a cook in a high school cafeteria for many years. One time she learned that a small café was available for rent; seeing her opportunity, she decided to start operating it. Summer months turned out to be even more successful than she expected, so Janylkan soon bought the café. Currently, this restaurant owner also rents a second café where she offers a menu of both national and European meals, earning a total monthly income of 40,000 soms, while the initial capital was 25,000 soms. Janylkan would like to spend her portion of the loan on furnishings and foodstuffs for the café, and in the long run hopes to open a restaurant in the capital as well. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

properties.title: Marco Tulio Mora Corrales : Costa Rica
properties.description: $850 of $1,025 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 6, 2011 Marco Tulio is 66 years old, married and lives with 2 children and his wife, who are his biggest priority. He intends to use the loan to buy the supplies needed to help his coffee plantation. He has land that is optimal for planting this crop, as well as the experience to do so. He has the field already in good condition, but wants to give it some extra assistance to improve the next harvest. He wants to generate profits for the well-being of his family, and to have a little money extra to later continue forward as a coffee grower. This is the first loan he has received from FUDECOSUR. He has not had previous loans with state banks, but FUDECOSUR has granted the loan with greater ease and at a much lower interest rate.

properties.title: La Amistad Centro (Cuenca) Group : Ecuador
properties.description: $1,825 of $3,100 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 27, 2011 The “La Amistad Centro” (The Friendship Center) Communal Bank is comprised of five women and three men. They are friends and acquaintances who live in the outskirts of the city of Cuenca. This city was named the Cultural Heritage of Humanity in December, 1999. The city has a widely varied gastronomy, which captivates the palate of natives and foreigners. Its people are warm and friendly. The members of this group are hard-working people who struggle day to day in order to get their families ahead. Rosa is one of the members of the communal bank. She lives in the outskirts of the city of Cuenca. She is 42 years old and married. She has two children, ages 23 and 18. Her first child, a son, works to cover his personal expenses. Her second child, a daughter, attends a school in the city. Her husband is out of the country. She does not have her own house, so she lives in a rented home. Rosa has had a bazaar for seven years. She tends this business from Monday through Friday from nine in the morning until seven at night. This is her first loan with the communal bank, which she was invited to join by a neighbor. She will use the money from the loan to buy items for her bazaar.

properties.title: Jefferson Rodulfo : Philippines
properties.description: $375 of $650 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 28, 2011 Jefferson is 31 years of age. He is married and is blessed with 2 children. He has been growing rice for almost 5 years. From his last crop, his net income was 30,000 PHP. Jefferson is asking for a loan of 28,000 PHP to purchase additional farm inputs such as seedlings and fertilizers. He hopes that KIVA lenders will continue assisting him in the business so that he can further improve it and support his family with enough basic necessities.

properties.title: Un : Cambodia
properties.description: $525 of $700 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 3, 2011 Mrs. Un is a 45-year-old married woman who currently resides in Dongkor commune of Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. She and her husband work in the farm field as local rice farmers. She started this occupation many years ago. Mrs. Un is blessed with nine kids; four are married and the other five are single. Two of them are working in a garment factory. This family’s living conditions are not so good because the house that they have lived in for a long time needs to be repaired but they have not enough cash to mend it yet. Because of this problem, Mrs. Un requested a loan in order to fix her old house so she and her family can live in a comfortable house.

properties.title: Patricia Wambui : Kenya
properties.description: $425 of $575 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 27, 2011 Patricia has operated her fruit shop in Njabini town for the last 4 years. She is 44 years old, married to Mwangi and they have 3 children. She was introduced to KADET by one of our field officers and this will be her fourth loan. She paid all her previous loans well and in good time. She plans to use the loan amount to buy more fruits and vegetables to sell in her shop. In the future, Patricia hopes to grow her shop to a big grocery store.

properties.title: Jesús Salvador Alcaráz Benitez : Colombia
properties.description: $150 of $575 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 3, 2011 “La Tienda de Jesús” (Jesús’ Store) is the name this entrepreneur decided to give his business. He sells basic household items and is located in Medellín. At the age of 60, employment opportunities were few which led Jesús to start this business four years ago. At present, Jesús needs a loan to buy some items like, rice, oil, and beans, among others, that will make it possible for him to offer greater variety to his customers thus increasing sales and improving profits.

properties.title: Razia's Group : Pakistan
properties.description: $475 of $725 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 8, 2011 Razia is 41 years old, married and has four children. Her two eldest sons are daily wage laborers, her youngest son is illiterate and her daughter is studying in class 9th.
