Her husband is a mason and provides construction services to different construction companies and people looking to build homes. He is the only breadwinner in the family. Razia is a caring lady, carrying out her responsibilities of a housewife very well. She cooks food for her family and keeps her house clean. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to financially assist her husband who wants to buy masonry tools that will allow him to provide better quality services to his customers and increase his profits. He has been operating this business for the past 15 years and Razia is hopeful that after the loan investment, he will be able to improve his income further. Razia is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her third loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained a good credit record and never missed any meeting. Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Razia.

properties.title: Faustina : El Salvador
properties.description: $750 of $1,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 23, 2011 Faustina lives with her life partner near the place where she works. She has a food business that is highly recommended in the area. In addition, the place where her business is located is very busy because it is close to a bus terminal. Faustina is a woman who is dedicated to her work and who always greets her customers with a smile on her face. The food that she prepares has an unparalleled flavor, and she sells her food at very affordable prices. Because of this, she has attracted more customers, and she does not want them to be disappointed. For this reason she is requesting a loan from INTEGRAL that will allow her to buy supplies such as staple grains, sausages, meat, vegetables, dairy products, drinks, and other products. In this way, she will always have food to offer her customers, and this will put her ahead of the competition. Faustina has faith that with the love and dedication she puts into her work, she will be given the opportunity to bring economic stability and a better quality of life to her family.

properties.title: Chichicazapa Group : Mexico
properties.description: $2,775 of $3,250 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 In the state of Oaxaca there is a community called Nuevo Paso Nazareno, or Chichicazapa, which is an indigenous community where all of the inhabitants speak the Mazateco dialect. Here there is a communal bank (made up of 10 people) that carries the "Chichicazapa," name of its community, because this is the name they identify with the most. This group has 10 members. One of the members of this group is Amada. She is 20 years old, single, and completed only two years of secondary school. She tells us that now she lives with her parents and two of her brothers. Ever since she left school she started to work, but since her community is small there are not a lot of job opportunities so she decided to start her own business selling pork meat. She makes her sales on Wednesdays, but the day before she offers her meat to her friends and neighbors in the community. The next day, after seasoning the pork, she delivers her orders. She tells us that selling pork is a difficult and arduous business because days before she has to go out to the other towns to buy the pig that she will prepare, and at times it is very difficult to find a pig and she has to go very far from Playa Vicente. But she is a very tenacious woman, since she has to support her family and also her youngest brother, who has a hurt leg. Amada needs this loan to invest in the purchase of pigs, feed and plastic bags to make her sales. She tells us that she hopes that with this loan her business will prosper. She wants to provide a better quality of life to her parents and brothers, and she also hopes that her brothers will have the opportunity to study a profession so that in the future they will have a better life. The other members of the group are: Minerva- who sells chicken Juana- who sells soft drinks Sara- who sells clothing Cecilia-who sells drinks Margarita - who sells traditional Mexican snacks Marcelina- who sells traditional Mexican snacks Edith- who sells drinks Juana- who sells meat Luisa- who sells drinks

properties.title: Kawral Group : Senegal
properties.description: $3,350 of $3,775 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 1, 2011 The Kawral Group was created in July of 2008 at the inauguration of their village bank. It is made up of 26 women who are from the same village. Their primary business is petty trading. Madam Néné is in charge of the group. She is 51 years old, married, and the mother of four children. She also looks after three nephews. She sells rice, vegetable and palm oil. She has valuable experience in this area, having practiced this business for many years. This new loan will allow her to resupply with rice, oil, and onions for resale. With the profits she reaps from her business, she intends to strengthen her shop and support her husband in sending the children to school.

properties.title: Kadidu Group : Uganda
properties.description: $700 of $1,200 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 8, 2011 Strong willed Emmanuel, 42, has been engaged in a pharmacy business the past eight years. His pharmacy is in Kayunga Town in Central Uganda. He says he started this business immediately after the completion of his medical studies at one of Uganda's best universities. Before that, the hardworking, tenacious and ambitious father of five was principally engaged in a modest pig sales trade. He still runs his pig sales business. He also does some small scale farming. He says this business generates profits to the tune of 120,000 UGX weekly. With this loan, he says he will be able to purchase more drugs to resell.

properties.title: Elnur Shirinov : Azerbaijan
properties.description: $1,225 of $1,925 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 28, 2011 Elnur is a responsible father of two children. He started his business seven years ago. Thanks to his valuable knowledge of the livestock trade, he has been able to obtain good results from his sales. His wife, a housekeeper, actively helps him in his business. This young man wishes to invest more capital in young animals. With the help of loan from KIVA he was able to improve and expand his business. Elnur hopes to continue his dedication to his work, believing that by improving his stock and feed, his cattle will bring better prices. For this reason, he haas applied for 1500 AZN to continue developing his business.

properties.title: Dios Es Mi Pastor 5 & 7 Group : Dominican Republic
properties.description: $3,075 of $3,375 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 22, 2011 Tomas is the coordinator of the Group Dios es mi pastor 5 & 7 (God is my Shepherd), located in the city of San Pedro de Macoris, where the primary economic activities are commerce, industrial cement plants, and household and cosmetic products. Tomas sells shoes, such as sneakers, casual shoes and slippers, and many cosmetics products. With this new loan, she is planning to invest in both to expand her inventory. Tomas is very excited to receive her second loan from Esperanza International, after having successfully repaid her previous loan and thus having taken a step towards expanding her business. Her challenges are raising and educating her three children. She lives with them and her long-term partner. She is planning to reinvest her profits in her business. Tomas is a very hardworking and young mother of only 26 years old. She is hoping to make her dreams come true, to have a prosperous life and a good business. She thanks all of you for your support!

properties.title: Suha Imteir : Palestine
properties.description: $1,500 of $2,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 27, 2011 Suha is a 49-year-old mother of four daughters and six sons. Two of her sons are not able of taking care of their families as they are outside Palestine. Suha and her husband take care of her two sons' families. Their two sons are unable to care for their families at this time not because they are not good husbands, but due to factors related to the political situation in Palestine. Suha and the family have a grocery store which is the only source of income for the entire family. Suha took out a loan from FATEN to pay for a variety of grocery items in order to attract more customers and have a better income to support such a big family. Suha is a conservative woman therefore her son is photographed instead of her.

properties.title: Sagrada Familia Group : Peru
properties.description: $2,950 of $3,850 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 4, 2011 Ms. Anita is divorced, has three children, and is currently a member of the "Sagrada Familia" ("Holy Family") communal bank, a group comprised of 16 members who work in various types of commerce. Anita has been working for five years in a bodega [small grocery store] installed in her house. She sells groceries like milk, sugar, and rice, as well as sweets, cookies, candies, etc. This work arose from her divorce, as she was left alone with her children and had to support them. Her motivation to keep moving was her children, so she worked very hard to get her family ahead. Thanks to her effort and dedication, she has achieved better economic results, which is how her children are able to attend school, how she can buy things, and above all how her family has a better quality of life. She has requested a new loan with the goal of continuing to grow and in order to buy merchandise (milk, sugar, rice, sweets). We know that Anita will meet her goals through a lot of work and effort, and that the loans through Edaprospo will help her.

properties.title: Naira Matevosyan : Armenia
properties.description: $875 of $2,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 4, 2011 Naira was born in 1974 and lives in Yerevan with her husband and 5-year-old son. She is an accountant and has a Bachelor's degree in economics. After university Naira worked as an accountant in different organizations. Three years ago Naira with her husband set up their own bakery in rented place. They produce various sorts of bread and "lavash" (typical Armenian flat unleavened wheat bread). Naira’s parents-in-law help with the business and her husband distributes their production to city food shops. Thanks to the profit from their business, Naira and her family bought the necessary furniture for their house and also they are able to support Naira’s and her parents-in-law families. Naira is asking for a $ 2,000 loan to buy flour supplies, oil, yeast, etc. for her bakery.

properties.title: Dalal Abu Olaya : Jordan
properties.description: $1,775 of $1,850 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 28, 2011 Dalal is a 27-year-old housewife who has three children to raise with her husband Ibrahim. Ibrahim has a full-time job working at one of the governmental entities in Jordan, but that was not enough income for the family, so he and Dalal decided to start a trading business, selling birds at home on their roof. Now, as a way to support her husband Dalal decided to take a loan to buy other kinds of birds and to improve the living area and the environment where the birds are kept. Since Dalal is a conservative person, she requested that her husband be in the picture instead of her.

properties.title: Israel Campos : United States
properties.description: $9,075 of $9,250 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 29, 2011 Israel describes his business, "Campos Collision and Auto Repair", as a family affair. The staff is comprised of Israel, his father and his brother. With a true entrepreneurial spirit, he states that the reason for starting his business was, simply, that “nobody was hiring.” With combined 40 years of experience, Israel and his family were able to take the grim reality of the economic downturn and turn it into a business opportunity. The road to a successful business, Israel says, hasn’t been an easy one. When he opened his business, which offers a wide range of automobile services from mechanical repairs to body work, it was located in a small shop in a residential neighborhood that wasn’t a prime location for a body shop. The most successful business choice Campos Auto Repair has made since it opened was moving from its original shop in Rueda, Texas, to a larger shop in Dallas. Of this choice, Israel says, “We took a leap of faith and moved to Dallas, and we just started growing based on referrals alone.” While he is happy about the business’ success in its new location, Israel is constantly driving to grow and expand the services he offers. “In the future, I would really like to offer full-service everything – state inspections and alignments in a year or two, and, eventually, one or two other locations,” he says. Getting to this future goal involves tireless work from Israel and his family – the shop is open for business 7 days a week, and Israel is typically there from open to close. With this loan, Campos Auto Repair was able to attain the operating capital needed to begin working in its new location. A large portion of the loan was used to install the plumbing systems necessary to get certified by the state. The remainder allowed Israel to buy an inspection machine, which will be used to further him toward his goal of turning Campos Auto into a full-service shop. Israel’s business ethic is rooted in a dedication to good customer service. The advice that he gives to aspiring business owners is that “the biggest thing is return customers; always take care of your customers, and in return they will take care of you.” This loan has allowed Israel to continue doing work he loves, expand his family business and continue to reliably serve the automobile needs of his Dallas community.

properties.title: C4714 Intwari Group : Rwanda
properties.description: $1,050 of $1,350 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 4, 2011 Marianne is 36 years old and married. She has three children between 5 and 11 years old. She is the president of a group called “Intwari.” She is the first person in her group. Marianne sells various goods such as rice, sugar, bread and biscuits. Marianne employs two persons for help her and has been working for two years. Marianne and her group have requested a loan from Kiva lenders in order to purchase more goods such as beans, cassava, maize, rice, sugar, bread, etc., to sell. With the profits from the loan, Marianne and her team would like to satisfy the basic needs of their families, reinvest in their businesses and start saving.

properties.title: Oñondivepa Group : Paraguay
properties.description: $1,950 of $2,325 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 5, 2011 The Oñondivepa committee has fifteen members. All of them are friends and neighbors from the town of Mariano Roque Alonso. The committee arose because one of the members had heard people talking about the program for entrepreneurial women, and since they liked the idea a lot, they organized themselves and formed the committee. These women describe themselves as very hard-working people who struggle each day to provide sustenance for their families. They affirm that all of their sacrifices are for their children and family members; they want to provide a better life for their families than the one they experienced. Angelina works selling clothing for all seasons of the year. Through this valued profession, she has been able to provide a decent living for herself and her family. She is proud that thanks to her work, the people who depend on her will have access to a better future. She is requesting the loan to buy more clothing, in order to renew her stock for future resale. She is grateful to the Paraguaya Foundation for the opportunity provided to her.

properties.title: Salwan Jabbar Mahdi : Iraq
properties.description: $1,950 of $3,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 5, 2011 This borrower is from Iraq. He is 19 years old and married. Salwan has had a shop for entertainment and electronic games since 2008. He has a deep understanding of local consumer needs and he is well known in his area. He is requesting a $3,000 loan to renovate and enlarge his shop. He is optimistic about his business development and hopes that the coming years will continue to bring him positive growth.

properties.title: Anonymous : Lebanon
properties.description: $1,025 of $1,500 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 11, 2011 This Kiva borrower is a 27-year-old Lebanese single man living with his parents and one sibling. He has six years of experience working with mobile phones. Then he opened his own store four years ago. With his loan requested of $1500 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. he will be able to increase his merchandise selection of new mobile phones and purchase prepaid telephone cards to sell. He notes that both his income and business productivity will be increased as a result of the loan. In the future, he is looking to further expand his business and increase his capital.

properties.title: Pamela Asweto : Kenya
properties.description: $400 of $450 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 30, 2011 Pamela is a married woman with five children, three attend school while two have graduated. She lives at a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees. For the past 10 years, she has operated a food vending business, cooking chapati (flatbread), beans and rice. She also sells detergent and clothes, which contributes another source of income. Pamela faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of expanding her business and establishing a restaurant in the future. With the KES 40,000 loan, she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and washing detergent. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

properties.title: Margarita Consuelo Castro Moran : Ecuador
properties.description: $300 of $1,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 5, 2011 56-year old Margarita liveslives in an urban area in the Orquídeas section of Guayaquil. (Las Orquídeas means "The Orchids", so called because it originally had many orchid flowers). Her husband is a master bricklayer. They have children. Margarita sells food and beauty products. She started her business some time ago because she enjoys selling. Before that she didn’t have a regular job. She decided to sell lunches in her neighbourhood and at the same time beauty products and cosmetics. Margarita works every morning preparing the lunches, and in the afternoons she sells the other items. With the loan money she wishes to buy more merchandise and Yanbal beauty products. In the future she would like to open a restaurant in her home.

properties.title: Sohoué : Benin
properties.description: $500 of $1,100 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 1, 2011 Born in Benin on September 10, 1952, Sohoué is a widow who lives alone with one of her children. Sohoué has four children, who all went to school; one still depends on her. Sohoué only went to primary school. To support herself and her children, Sohoué has been retailing firewood from her home for almost 30 years. In parallel to this business, Sohoué sells ice. Thanks to the revenues generated by her activities, Sohoué is able to properly provide for her family. Sohoué gets her supplies from Benin's largest market. In the pursuit of customer satisfaction and to improve her standard of living and income, Sohoué is requesting a loan from ALIDé for the first time.

properties.title: Petrona De Los Angeles Quezada Torrez : Nicaragua
properties.description: $225 of $500 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 23, 2011 Petrona De Los Ángeles has had a grocery store for over six years. She is a very hard-working person. She started this way of life as a work alternative because she did not have the means to get the income needed to support her family. She needed to provide them with their daily bread. The reason for the loan is to buy products like sweets, detergent, basic grains, juice, soft drinks, and others. She dreams of improving her income each day. She has always liked to work and to provide what is necessary.

properties.title: Naseem's Group : Pakistan
properties.description: $350 of $1,075 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 25, 2011 Naseem is a 51-year-old married woman with two children: a son and a daughter. Her son got his education to the 8th standard and now works as a salesman. Her daughter got her education to the 5th standard and learned the skill of embroidery from Naseem. Naseem is a housewife, managing her household work by staying at home. In her spare time, she also does sewing for neighbors and makes some money to manage the household expenses. Her husband is a carpenter by profession and makes furniture on order. He is very skillful in his work and makes beautiful furniture designs for his clients. Naseem has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner, Asasah, for her son’s business. With the loan, her son will buy edible items such as Nimko, biscuits and chips, etc., to be able to meet his clients' orders and earn profit. Naseem is hopeful that her son's business will be well established after investing in it, and her family will be able to enjoy a better standard of living as a result.

properties.title: Marlon Salvanera : Philippines
properties.description: $725 of $1,175 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Marlon is 45 years old and lives in Poblacion 1, Clarin, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. He is married and a father of four school-aged children. Marlon own a small convenience store in his town. He sells groceries, feed, medicine, and mobile loads and refills gas tanks. He has been running his business for six years with a monthly income of PHP 5,000. He requested a loan of PHP 50,000 from GDMPC to purchase additional stock to sell. Marlon had been a member of GDMPC for more than eight years. In the future, Marlon hopes to have more convenience stores in the city.

properties.title: Jean : Liberia
properties.description: $800 of $975 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 8, 2011 Jean is 31 years old and lives in West Point. He is married and attends college. His wife is a business woman and they have one child, six years old. For the past six years, Jean has been operating a small shop where he sells sneakers, shoes, and also charged mobile phones. What he likes most is that most of the time he doesn’t run out of money, and the profit he earns is used for upkeep of his home. He is requesting a loan to purchase more shoes and sneakers. He hopes to have an international business in the near future.

properties.title: Rogelio : El Salvador
properties.description: $200 of $750 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 27, 2011 Rogelio is a farmer. He is married and lives with his wife; they have 5 children aged 14, 12, 7, and 4 years old and a baby of 6 months. He works planting corn, beans and sorghum. He has worked with crops since he was young, as it was a profession instilled in him by his father. His working hours are from 6:00 am to 11:00 am, and this work allows him to feed his children. He is requesting a loan to buy fertilizers for the planting of corn and sorghum. The purpose is to have the materials to begin the task of the second season of planting of the year. He holds hope that the winter won't bring too much rain or dry times, as either of these phenomena would damage the crop. His goal is to have the strength to work and raise his children, giving them the opportunity to study, eat and grow healthily. As his family is very large, it requires a lot of effort to cover household expenses.

properties.title: El Pinito Group : Mexico
properties.description: $2,000 of $3,250 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 This group is called 'El Pinito' (The Little Pine Tree). The members gave the group this name because there is a small pine tree in the place where they meet. This story is about Irma who is the group's representative. She is 40 years old, married, and has four children: Esteban, Mariela, Mariano and Abigail. Only two of her children are studying. One is in his first year of a law degree and her youngest is in her second year of high school. The two eldest children are already married. Irma has owned a grocery store for 11 years. Irma tells us that she decided to start out in this business because she wanted a way to support her children and provide them with a better quality of life. In addition, this business allows her to attend to her children and not neglect them. She is also able to support her husband with their household expenses. Irma used the loan that she requested to invest in buying more sweet treats, soft drinks, water and juice for this hot season which is unbearable. Irma's goal is to provide her children with an excellent quality of life. She would also like to grow her business a lot more. She is thinking of building premises in order to set up a grocery store so that she can offer her customers a wider range of products in order to improve and increase her profits. Irma says that all her fellow group members are responsible people who meet their obligations and really enjoy working in order to improve themselves and get ahead even when faced with difficulties. Irma gives thanks to Fundación Realidad and Kiva on behalf of herself and her family. Thanks to them, she will be able to improve her own life and that of her family. They will now have an excellent quality of life and financial solvency. The members of the "El Pinito" group and the businesses that they are engaged in are as follows: Áraceli - chicken sales Juljencia - clothes sales Clementina - cosmetics sales Aristea - selling tamales Jeronima - clothes sales María - selling sewing supplies Adilene - selling sweet potatoes Priciliana - selling sweet potatoes Irma - selling sweet treats Juana - selling bread Rogaciana - selling bread Felicitas - selling tamales

properties.title: Sant Yalla Group : Senegal
properties.description: $3,100 of $4,550 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 1, 2011 This group was created on June 27, 2008. It is made up of 17 members who come from the same district. Their principal business is selling various small items. Madame Rokheyatou, on the far right, is the leader of the group. Her business is selling fish. She has a lot of experience in this activity as she has been working in this field for more than two years. Her loan will allow her to stock up on fish. Her goal is to build her own house and to see to the education of her children.

properties.title: Blanca : Bolivia
properties.description: $725 of $1,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 6, 2011 Blanca has been selling prepared breakfast and lunch foods in the Los Pozos market for more than 10 years. She is a very well known person in the food sector and she has good references. Blanca has 3 grown children and only her 16-year old daughter is still dependent. They have lived in the region of La Pampa de la Isla for more than three years. Her husband has been a taxi driver for more than 2 years. Blanca leases a stand in Los Pozos from where she sells her foods. She also rents another area where she keeps all her chairs, tables, ovens, and carafes. But some months when her sales are high she uses both spaces. She has four people working for her, a master chef, two assistant cooks, and a waitress who attends approximately 20 tables. Her food sales are significant and her business is established and she has many clients. The Los Pozos market is a center of massive consumption with a good influx of cash. The funds for this loan will be used to purchase construction materials to repair a bathroom in her house. She is a very hardworking person and she is thankful with the institution for the support given her.

properties.title: Ahmad Wadaa Naji : Iraq
properties.description: $2,550 of $3,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 21, 2011 This borrower is from Iraq. He is 31 years old and married. Ahmad has owned a bakery since 2005. He has more than five years experience; his bakery is situated in a crowded area so there are a good number of customers passing by and he has a good reputation. He is requesting a $3000 loan to renovate his shop and to make ceramic tiles. He is aiming to gain more profits so he can improve his family's quality life.

properties.title: Seraphine : Rwanda
properties.description: $500 of $850 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 8, 2011 Seraphine is 40 years old and is married. She has five children. She sells goods such as water, biscuits and toilet paper in her small boutique. She has three years of experience and she employs one person to help her. She works from 8 a.m. until 8 p.m. every day except on the weekend. Seraphine has requested her first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase more goods such as water, biscuits and toilet paper for resale. With any profits, Seraphine will reinvest in her business and pay her children's school fees.

properties.title: Marina Pacheva : Ukraine
properties.description: $1,325 of $1,900 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 20, 2011 Marina is married with a son and a daughter. Her family of four lives in the town of Melitopol. Marina sells leather accessories in the local ‘Rizhskyi' market, i.e. purses, wallets, folders, etc. She launched her enterprise 14 years ago. Presently, Marina has 35,000 grivnyas in inventory. Her net profit amounts to 5,000 grivnyas a month. Marina is planning to invest the loan of 15,000 Grivnyas in the purchase of assorted women's purses. She is hoping to meet the demands of her female clients offering them a nice selection of purses and handbags at reasonable prices that will please different tastes. Marina likes working with this type of merchandise. She is hoping to keep growing her trade and open an additional vending location in the future.

properties.title: Anonymous : Lebanon
properties.description: $1,600 of $2,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 25, 2011 This Kiva borrower is a 43-year-old married woman from Lebanon. She is living with her husband and four children, two of whom are still attending school. She has owned a mini-market in her village since 2009. She sells in her grocery store all types of food products like juices, breads etc. She cooperates with her husband who works in the construction field to be able to handle the heavy living expenses. Today, she is requesting to borrow $2,000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to improve her business and further expand it by increasing her store’s inventory. She is very positive and hopes that the loan will help her achieve a significant growth in her business.

properties.title: Jorge Washington : Ecuador
properties.description: $1,125 of $1,200 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 27, 2011 Jorge Washington is 26 years old, he is married and lives with his wife and children. He lives in the Ventanas Canton in the Province of Los Rios. This group is called SAN FRANCISCO DE SIBIMBE, and it is located in the Sibimbe precinct which is part of the Ventanas Canton. This group has 20 members who work in short-cycle agriculture, planting corn and rice. Jorge works in agriculture, planting corn and rice. He works on his parents' land. He makes purchase in Ventanas every month and sells at the market in the same locality. He is requesting the loan for the purchase of products for the farming of corn and rice. The support from this loan would help him financially to meet his needs. They are not facing any very important challenges. His dream is to buy his own land to work. He likes to go for walks with his family and to make purchases in the market.

properties.title: Mendkhuu Tserendulam : Mongolia
properties.description: $1,725 of $2,800 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 4, 2011 Mendkhuu, aged 49, and her husband, Erdenebileg, have been working hard to get ahead and support their family. She has been working as a pastry-cook at a local food manufacturing company for over seven years. Her husband is one of the operations staff at Nomin Holding Co.,Ltd. They live in a traditional Mongolian yurt “ger” in the outer district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She is the mother of three adult children aged 24, 27 and 29. Her daughter, Uranjargal, stays with her parents and attends college, studying Business Financial Management. The youngest son is living and working in Korea while his brother lives separately with his family in Ulaanbaatar and runs a taxi business. Mendkhuu is requesting a 3,500,000 MNT (Mongolian Tugriks) loan to invest in buying a small log house for her son. It is tough for her children living apart. As a mother, she is striving to make their lives better. She is very grateful to the institute and the lenders for giving her an opportunity to achieve her goal as well as to make a big change in her son's life.

properties.title: Senyi Tusitukirewamu Group : Uganda
properties.description: $1,600 of $4,500 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 4, 2011 Rose, 50, says anybody who believes can notch up something worthwhile in whatever they do. Rose believed she could be a business owner and she had the markings to have success at her grasp. This was 20 years ago. To get her food sales business on its feet, Rose had to play many trump cards. That belief in her own worth was, needless to say, already playing in her favor, but she needed to back it up with hard work, determination and building relationships with many people including potential money lenders. Once the stage was set, she took root and has never looked back. She sells foods such as bananas, cassava, maize, beans, rice, etc. in food markets in Lugazi. Rose also does farming as a side source of income. Weekly, her food sales business is worth 100,000 net profits. With this loan, she says she is going to purchase more foods such as maize, cassava, cabbage, rice, beans to resell.

properties.title: Mema Alvior : Philippines
properties.description: $500 of $575 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 2, 2011 Mema is 45 years old and married with four children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a rice shop in the Philippines and requested a 25,000 Philippine peso (PHP) loan through NWTF to purchase additional sacks of rice to sell. Mema has borrowed and repaid 14 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running her rice shop for eight years and also earns an income from being a motorcycle operator. Mema hopes to build and expand her business and send her children to college.

properties.title: Dios Es Bueno 1, 2 & 3 Group : Dominican Republic
properties.description: $3,700 of $4,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 27, 2011 Margarita is excited to be taking her second loan with Esperanza. She is the coordinator of her group Dios es bueno 1, 2 & 3 (God is Great). Margarita's group is located in the rural areas surrounding La Romana, where the sugarcane harvest and tourist industry dominate the economy. This area, like nearly all impoverished areas of the Dominican Republic, suffers from unreliable running water (none of which is potable) and electricity. Her community is a batey, where most of the citizens are Haitians who emigrated to work in different industries in the Dominican Republic. This group is composed of 15 Haitian businesswomen. Margarita has had her business for around a year. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business by purchasing bread, jam, cheese, fruits, sugar and snacks for her food stall, where she will add more meals, such as rice, beans and meat to sell for lunch. Her profits will be used as savings because her children will start school again in about 3 months and she need the money for their school supplies. Margarita makes her home in a simple structure with her four children and her long term partner. She says that her most difficult challenge is to educate and raise her children in a foreign country and to provide what her spouse can't. By working and selling, she helps to bring income to her household. In the meantime, she plans to continue enjoying to cook and have fun with her family by watching tv and doing other activities.

properties.title: Abena Tawiah : Ghana
properties.description: $275 of $800 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 5, 2011 Abena is married and has two children. Her husband is a taxi driver. Abena went to a vocational school. She has been a hairdresser at Abura for four years. She assists her husband to provide the basic needs of the family. Her loan will be used to buy more hair creams, lotions, etc. to use on her customers. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to buy an additional hairdryer.

properties.title: Aisha Mwelela : Kenya
properties.description: $200 of $450 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 25, 2011 Asha is a married woman with two children. One of her children attends school and the other is too young. Asha owns a house that has electricity and piped water and her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. For the past two years, Asha has operated a boda boda (motorcycle transport) business. Her customers are her neighbors and passersby. Asha’s main business challenge is delayed payments by her customers. She dreams of owning a matatu (public service vehicle) in the future. Asha decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. She is requesting a loan of 40,000 KES to start a clothing business and purchase clothes and cloth material to sell.

properties.title: Lina Lanh : Cambodia
properties.description: $525 of $1,000 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 7, 2011 Lina sells coffee and tea. He buys the coffee and tea from Vietnam and sells it in other provinces. His wife Net sells food at home. They have been married for over twelve years, and they live in a village about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. This is Lina's second Kiva loan. This loan request is for $1,000 to put an addition on his house.

properties.title: Veronika Ñiquen Sandoval : Peru
properties.description: $250 of $725 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 2, 2011 Verónika is 30 years old and has lived with her parents for 10 years due to her separation from her husband. The house where Verónika lives is in the Eten-Chiclayo district. This is a developing community, made up of enterprising people who have a great desire to succeed. Verónika has a grocery store in her own home. The grocery store has a large influx of customers due to the high quality of service she has offered for the last 3 years, and also the variety of products that her store stocks. Verónika has an established clientele to whom she sells her products for credit and cash. She wants to invest in her business as it brings her great satisfaction. This is why Verónika aims to expand her grocery store, and make it the best stocked in her community. To achieve her objectives, Verónika has requested a loan of 2,000 New Soles through Edpyme Alternativa which will go towards buying groceries, snacks and drinks to help her stock her business. She will also buy a refrigerator to improve her quality of life.

properties.title: Ana Lilian : El Salvador
properties.description: $100 of $800 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 24, 2011 Ana sells cosmetics. She has a house of her own and lives with two children and her husband. Her business is home-based and she also goes out to sell door to door. She’s been in business 14 years and to date, thanks to God, she’s had no difficulties. She requests a loan to buy merchandise like lotions, creams, shampoo, makeup and underwear. With the loan she will attain her project of increasing merchandise and offering customers more variety of beauty products. Her goal is to have a stable business with a fixed locale in the market so she will be better known and her income will improve.

properties.title: Iratwibutse I Group : Burundi
properties.description: $2,625 of $4,750 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 26, 2011 Espérance is a 28-year-old merchant living in the neighborhood of Gatumba in the municipality of Bujumbura. She has been selling foodstuff (like cabbages, onions and tomatoes) for two years, a business that she launched when she sold kitchen utensils from door to door. She is married to Jean-Paul, a driver. Together they have three children who attend school. She cares also for two children of her close relatives. Espérance studied until sixth grade in elementary school. She will use her share of 150,000 Burundi francs in the group loan to increase her working capital in order to buy more food products for sale and make a large profit. Espérance is a member of the community group of Iratwibutse I.

properties.title: María Del Carmen Aguinaga : Nicaragua
properties.description: $225 of $450 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 27, 2011 María del Carmen is 57 years old. She is a hard-working and entrepreneurial woman who has five children. She tells us that all of her children are fine, upstanding men and women. María has been selling fruit, vegetables, basic grains and other products for several years. She will invest this loan in buying seasonal fruit and vegetables in order to strengthen her business.

properties.title: Brissawé : Togo
properties.description: $325 of $450 raised. Started raising funds on Jun 24, 2011 Brissawé is a 38-year-old woman. She is married to an accountant. They have two children. Brissawé has worked as a retailer since 1996. She sells pagnes (a type of brightly-printed West African cloth) and damask door-to-door. She buys her goods at the Grand Market in Lomé and in Mali. Brissawé has requested her second loan through WAGES (one of Kiva's field partners) in order to buy 10 sets of damask of the "riche" variety.

properties.title: Akpedji Group : Benin
properties.description: $125 of $450 raised. Started raising funds on Jul 5, 2011 Group Akpedji is composed of three residents of the same district in Benin. The group's representative, named Julienne Rufine, is raising her hand on the picture. This is the first time that this group is requesting ALIDé's financial support in order to increase their level of activity. Julienne Rufine is 50 years old and a widow with four children, who all go to school. Among the children, only one still depends on her financially. She supports herself on her own. For this, Julienne Rufine is in the business of selling prepaid phone cards and various other products at a market in Benin. She gets her supplies from one of Benin's largest markets. She has been in this business for about fifteen years. To better satisfy her customers' demands, Julienne Rufine wishes to strengthen her activity by increasing her stock of products. To achieve this, Julienne Rufine and group Akpedji's other members are requesting a loan from ALIDé.
